text: Thanks to erzengel for sharing!! Pours a cola color without a head. The smell is very hot and boozey with plenty of peat and roast. The taste also burns with the same roasted malt, and dry peatiness coming through. Medium in body and without carbonation. Not my thing at all - its like drinking vodka out of an ashtray.

Intense thick roasted peated nose. Great round, no carbonation. The beer starts intense and thick, toffee, peated malt, very concentrated and hard to drink. Viscous. Intense and long roasted dried thick dark peated aftertaste, no depth, just thick, not too much alcohol, a bit sweetish, strange but interesting. But way too less depth.
Torfiger Geruch. Intensiver rauchiger Beginn, in dem die Süße nur eine Nebensache darstellt. Stark alkoholisch, langer Nachhall. Gut. 10/11/10/11/0/11

Sampled from 0.33 l bottle. Clear, dark brownish amber, no head. Very intense, peaty, slightly sweetish-malty aroma of mainly peat, some caramel and hints of vanilla. Extremely intense, malty and very peaty taste of massive peat, caramel and some vanilla, followed by a long, very peaty and warming-alcoholic finish. Full body, oily mouthfeel, flat. Really intense stuff, not bad actually, quite enjoyable, couldnt drink more than a few sips though.

Bottle shared with Zlotta and Koelschtrinker. Dunkel orange braunes Bier. Geruch ist alkoholisch, kräftig malzig, reifes Obst, holzig, Kaffee. Geschmack ist brennend alkoholisch, Melasse, toffee, Lakritze, brennend alkoholisch im Abgang.
Backlog: Aroma is sweet and spicey from alcohol. Taste is thick tar, smokey notes, chunks of wood and a burning alcohol sensation. Not my jam.
Bottle shared by Björn thanks. No head and clear brown color. Big roasted dark malty aroma. Very intense dark roasted malty taste.

Bottle (was agend about 10 years): Very dark brown color, no head. Aroma is very sharp alcoholic, dark maltsm raisins, dark dried fruits. Flavor is dense, chocolate, dark fruits, plums in rum, alchohol, cherries, cacao powder. Very good.
Dont know what to make of this so just giving it 50%. I couldnt drink it, was like a bad whiskey but maybe thats the point or maybe theres no point. I can safely say I wont ever drink it again,

Un produit atypique. Brune foncée à noire cette bière est une explosion de saveur en bouche. Une bière extra-ordinaire qui tranche les saveurs et les avis. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sweet vineous aroma like Port wine, dark syrup and fruity. Raisins, liquorice and coffee in the taste. Really interesting and much better than expected.

Piwo z pewnością kultowe, ciekawe, a przede wszystkim, bardzo mocne. 32% to nie wynik tradycyjnego procesu, a wymrażania. Oczywiście nie jest to trunek sesyjny, ale na spotkanie w pięcioosobowym gronie było idealne! Bardzo oleista konsystencja, ciemnobrązowe, bez piany, bez gazu... Aromat ciemnych, suszonych owoców, czekolady. Likierowy. W smaku mocy nie czuć. Czuć za to owoce, owoce w likierze, czekoladę. Całość tworzy bardzo smaczną kompozycję. Ciężko myśleć o Pingwinie jako o piwie, ale to i tak trunek wart uwagi! Ciekawe doznanie!

Taster @ Brewdog, helsinki. Intense dried plums and dark fruit, strong booze, some stingy acetone, spices. Unsurprisingly feels like a schnaps. Goes down easily though, warming and smooth. Sticky and oily, though. spectacular in all ways. and i love the name
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

9th Nov 2016: 375ml bottle between four at the monthly Shrewsbury beer exchange group meeting in Chez Sophie. Cheers Simon for trying to kill us all with this offering. Strong stuff isnt it! Actually I quite liked it. Thick, sticky and sweet: what is there not to like?

375ml bottle @ monthly tasting, Chez Sophie Oct 16, thanks to Simon! Pours pitch black, oily, no head. Aroma is quite something, huge molasses and liquorice. Taste is intense, continuing this with added coffee, dark fruits, treacle.. quite sticky, rich and super boozy. Intense stuff that ensured the next day was a complete write-off!

Its impossible to rate this crazy invention. I opened this bottle 2 years(!) ago, and I havent been able to write a reasonable rating before now. Should the Penguin be compared to an imperial stout? Should it be rated as a whisky? Should it be given extra points for being an absurd creation? Well, this is probably one of the most amazing liquids that has ever entered by mouth, so lets rate it as such. It is an extremely intense beer concentrate, with every element you find in a perfect barrel aged imperial stout turned up to 11. Chocolate, coffee, caramel, dark dried fruits, dark berries, oak, whisky, vanilla, alcohol... you just pick every random word that pops into your head when you think about "barrel aged imperial stout" and youll find it in this remarkable syrup. Its heavy sweet and heavy bitter, and the finish is everlasting. The pitch black body is not carbonated, but that doesnt bother me. Its a beer that can be stored for months after opening without degrading. I do not recommend keeping it for two years, though, some notes of wet paper and cardboard has started to become a bit too obvious. The first half year after opening, this is close to perfection. Wow. 
[repeated small samples from a 37.5 cl bottle, opened 9 years before BB date, from Vinmonopolet Vika, Oslo]

Bottled. A bottle brought from Slovakia to Canada for my friend Erik for his 40th birthday. Batch 915. Best before forever. Just kidding. Best before 2025. Pours a black and brown color. Pours like sirup, oil. Aroma of roasted malt, espresso, dried plums, licorice, plum marmalade and tons of booze. Epic! Taste is sweet, chocolate, plums, dried fruits, imperial stout, molasses stickiness. Dry boozy chocolate bitter finish. Epic experience!

Bottle to share. Pours black with no head. Aroma full of alcohol, licorice, dark chocolate and coffe. Full body, quite flat. It tastes mostly alcohol and coffe. I enjoy my Frank Zappa albums much more than I enjoy this beer.

Taster at Oluhuone Kaisla. Intense dried plums and dark fruit, strong booze, some stingy acetone, spices. Unsurprisingly feels like a schnaps. Goes down easily though, warming and smooth. Sticky and oily, though. Qualifies as a worthwhile experiment.
Taster at tap takeover. Deep, dark brown with a tan head. Loads of coffee and malts. Liquorice alcohol with a sweet caramel finish. Very boozy. Obvs.
bottle. Clear nut with no head. Malt and caramel aroma. Heavy sweet flavour, seems whisky

Pours a jet black color, with a reddish brown head. Aromas of espresso/chocolate and roasted malts with a wood like quality. Almost like this was aged in sherry casks. Taste is complex; dark roasted coffee and bittersweet chocolate malt with a smooth alcohol laced bite, also had some Sambuca like qualities, licorice and nut. This was an interesting stout with a flavor like nothing Ive tried before. Not sure if I would buy it again, but something everyone should try at least once.

próbka z butelki i na pewno więcej wypić byłoby trudno. w aromacie paloność, czekolada i alkohol kojarzący się z brandy. zaskakująco wodniste, sojowe, alkoholowość na bardzo wysokim poziomie, ale to wiadomo z etykiety. warto spróbować

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Przeklejka wyjazdowa, probka (dzieki, Swaroga!): Tactical Nuclear PenguinBrewDogPachnie wciaz jak wylezakowany stout!!! Przy czym delikatnie. W ustach gesty, slodki, sojowy, calkiem cacy. Wynalazek do sprobowania. PijalnOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).
Sampel butelki. Kolor czarny bez piany. Zapach palonosci i alkoholu. Zadziwiająco gładkie i mało spirytusowe jak na abv. Czuć tam stouta, palone slody, kakao. Niezle.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2016 Bez piany, czarne, nieprzejrzyste. Aromat stoutowy z zaznaczonym sosem sojowym, sisem teryaki i melasa. W smaku lekka slodycz, ciemne slody, sos sojowy. Mega geste w idczuciu. Jest alkohol, ale calkiem znosny.
Bottle share at glapivmag. Deep brown to black. Sweet malty aroma with lot of Alco. Taste is similar nutty, malty but Alco is way too strong.

Pours very dark brown. Strong alcohol in aroma, burns your nose. Also some caramel and raisin. Taste is strong, sharp. Little bit sourish, pepper, sugar, burned bread. Sticks in your lips, after reveals strong alcohol and stays pungent. Nice liquid to try!
Almost black liquid with brown foam. Aroma of alcohol, nuts, toffee. Tastes same, Heavy sweet, medium bitter, light sour. Full body, sticky, long finish.

Concentrated to the bone, cloying sweet with burned coal and alcohol bitterness and also some coffee like acidity. Its only possible to sip it very slowly cause its almost burning with alcohol and packed thickness. After a while its not even enjoyable anymore. Still a good companion with a cigar or a pipe. I also get some soy sauce notes that arent delicious.
From a bottle in a small glassware. The pour is a really dark red. The taste is a really sweet chocolate ,soy sauce texture, super boozey.
From bottle in Brewdog Newcastle. Pours mahogany with no head. The aroma is malty and very boozy. The taste is intense liquorice and spice. Very boozy obviously. I liked it a lot.
Bottle pours at Brewdog Shoreditch, courtesy of Ivan. Pours brown with no head. Oily. Roasted malts, wood, smoke, caramel, chocolate. Sweet. Warming and boozy.

duft: sødlig dadler rosin mørkt malt.
smag: meget markant alkohol. dadler rosin virklig varm sprittet eftersmag.

Quite a nice aroma of port, sherry, red wine, stone fruits. Dark as night with no head. Taste starts malty and sweet, develops to some caramel and then BOOM, burnt paper, char, ash, smoke, accompanied by a huge bitterness. The finish on this beer is brutal and punishing. Nice to say ive tried it, but its just too much.

Butelka zakupiona w firmowym sklepie BrewDoga w Londynie. Degustacja z kieliszka 0,1 ml. Gesty likier. Piany oczywi?cie brak, brak wysycenia. W zapachu mocny alkoholowy likier owocowy. Dodatkowo karmelu smaku rozgrzewaj?cy równie? lakierów posmak, s?odk? czekolada i ciemne owoce. 1 shot w zupe?no?ci wystarczy. Wi?cej nie da si? tego wypi? :)
Bottle. Pours dark amber in colour, sticky, no head. Aroma of cherries, caramel, some vanilla. In taste caramel and cherries with strong and long bitterness in the finish, not pleasant.
A shot at Brewdog in Leeds. Tasty and dry, but not surprisingly more of a spirit than a beer.
Sample at beertemple. Copper red pour. Strong aroma of booze, vanilla and glue. Taste has caramel, vanilla and licorice at first, but then the strong booze kicks in and takes over. This is a gimmick.
Flaska på Örebro ÖoW. Kolsvart med brunt skum. Tung doft med soja, choklad och karamell. Värmande sprit med söt smak och även lite syrligher.

Provsmakning örebro ölmässa. Kolsvart kulör. Doft av rostad malt, knäck och choklad. Lite spritigt .
Tjock munkänsla med russin, knäck, soja och sirap
Not for feint hearted, but perfect in place of a glass of port or whiskey at the end of the night

Bottle
Aroma-dark fruits, caramel, alcohol
Appearance-dark amber, clear, minimal tan foam, 
Taste-medium bitterness, medium sourness, light sweetness, 
Palate-full body, sticky, flat, long finish, 
Overall-very interesting

Bottle sample @ Briljant, Haarlem. Sweet, boozy aroma with chocolate and licorice, dark fruits, light iodine. Taste is sweet, boozy, aftertaste of alcohol, iodine, hint of chocolate somewhere in the aftertaste. Not bad.
Corked 37.5 cl bottle @ home shared with a few people. Pours black with virtually no head. Aroma and flavour are peat, iodine, roasted malt, and whiskey - with an alcoholic finish.

25cL at Brewdogs Bristol. Poured clear dark brown with no head. Powerful aroma very sweet like sherry malts burnt caramel and booze. No carb med bod. Concentrated stout taste roasted malts. Worried it would be awful but in small sips not bad. YOU WILL NOT ENJOY IN LARGE SIPS.

From the very old notes, hence this is not a real rating, but more just a mark to myself that I have tried this at one point. Not really a beer, just a product that reminds beer. Its very sweet and hoppy, alcohol is very noticeable. Still its a decent sipper if you are looking for strong beer like product.
Sampled from bottle. Black color with no head. Aroma is... alcohol.. malty, whiskey, wood. Taste is the same, hot alcohol. Medium to full oily sticky body with flat carbonation.
Rated based on notes taken 7 Sep 2014 -- Wheeeeew, 32%. This beer is heavy. And delicious. "Damn yo. I felt the presence of an anxious ghost."

Aromat wybitnie alkoholowy, lamelowy, chlebowy, miodowy, melano, chleb razowy. Barwa czarna nieprzejrzysta,  mega gęsta, oleista konsystencja. Piany brak. Smak słodki, oblepiający, razowy, czekoladowy, kawowy, ostry. Niezapomniany. Płem jedynie małą próbkę na urodzinach KIK-u bo cena zabójcza. Mimo wszystko, wszystkiego najlepszego!

Shot from a bottle at The Roebuck, Leek (Titanic) Pours a murky deep brown colour with no head. Aroma of gravy, cocoa, roasted malts, scotch whisky, liquorice, wood, alcohol, raisin and soy sauce. Initial taste of gravy, alcohol, soy sauce and cocoa, also dark fruit, port, even more cocoa, vanilla, treacle, cough syrup and whisky. Full bodied and a thick, syrupy texture. A full on, burning, cocoa finish. OMG! This is strong, like a spirit. Very chocolatey and similar to port. Not drinkable but like a novelty spirit. Worth it.
Black. Chocolate, syrup, alcohol, spice and oak. Sticky, sweet, alcohol finish. Overall: nice! what an experience.

Kolor brunatny. Pojawiła się lekka pianka. 
W aromacie mocne nuty stoutu. Jest czekoladowe, ale też palone. Trochę nut porterowych. Wyczuwalny alkohol. 
 W smaku mocne goryczkowe. Alkohol bardzo wyraźnie daje o sobie znać. Podnosi odczucie goryczki. Ale jest też sporo chmielu. 
Lekko kwaskowate nuty. 
Wszystko jest jak być powinno, to naprawdę dobry stout. 
Piwo gęste, co widać już przy nalewaniu. Ma konsystencję likieru. 
W odczuciu mocno alkoholowy, mocno grzeje w ustach.

32% ABV

Cork smells exactly like Abstrakt. Umami. Strong hints of Tamari.

Strong herbal notes with licorice lingering. No carbonation. Port like appearance.

Syrupy mouthfeel. Activates salty and savory taste receptors. Sweet on the front of the tongue. Has raspberries, prunes and dates on the sides of the tongue. Distracting alcoholic fumigation at this phase of tasting.

The palate has hints of well-worn cured leather.

Although no obvious carbonation, there is a pleasant carbonic tingle when sipped. This is an obscure homage to its beery origins.

When forced through and past the palate and up the nose and aerated this way, has earthy hints of freshly harvested shiitake.

The tail end of the 2nd glass releases some nice sour plum goodness. Surprising. It keeps unfolding...

When shooting, has nice caramel flavors, redolent with the richness of flan with caramel sauce, milky and creamy.

No point attempting to appreciate any change in the nose after the first go around, does not change and has the same musky, savory nose which does not mellow with oxygenation or breathing.

Overall, a very satisfying beer experience somewhat marred by the need for novelty, chiefly the outrageous alcohol content which made a quite remarkable imperial stout more difficult to enjoy than it shouldve been.

4cl from bottle @Harry?s. Pours dark brown with no head. Oily. Aroma is alcohol, dark fruits, coffee, dark malts, mud cake, chocolate... Rich aroma! Flavor is mud cake, black coffee, chocolate, alcohol, dark malts, dark bread and salty liquorice. Oily palate, not stingy beer at all! Swell!
Over the top stout, oatmeal chocolate liquorish. Sweet, very warm alcohol finish. Still very drinkable despite the high alcohol.

Bottle; pours black with no head; aroma of licorice, dark fruits, some chocolate, and a little booze; taste is rich and smooth with malt, chocolate, dark fruits, with some booze and licorice; finish is dry with some alcohol bitterness; very good
Bellissima, liquore, caffè , al naso si sente l?alcool. . Calda al palato.. da meditazione..

Pours black with no head. Aroma is of warming whiskey spiced booze, salty, oak, chocolate malts, and buttery toffee. It reminds me of a tasty sweet glazed meat. The flavor is rather rich of dark roasted malts, sweet burnt caramel syrup, some bitterness, and some vanilla. The finish is more of a roasted coffee liqueur without the dark coffee bitterness. Overall it is rather good. If you consider the potent nature of this brew it blends rather well. It remains vand very flavorful and is intriguing. I never had anything like this. I would recommend this beverage even that it is not your typical imperial stout style.
A: Chocolate! Liqourice, Hay, plum T: Smokey, Liqourice, salt, salmiak O: Very nice! Much better than expected! I really enjoy it, but a small glass OS enough.
Pours a viscous black with no head. Aroma is sweet molasses with slight dark chocolate notes. Taste is sweet malt, dark chocolate, slight leather with an alcohol burn. Thick as oil.
Not bad. A sweet think ans syrupy brew. Nice but not worth more than to satisfy curiosity. :-)

Small sample from a swingtop bottle in Edinburgh. 
Dark reddish-brown body looks quite thick. Smells much like a barleywine. Tastes like barleywine concentrate. 
Syrupy. No mistaking high ABV in the mouthfeel.
Boozy, but much less so than expected given the extraordinary ABV.

Aroma: toasted malts, coffee, salty, smoked flavours. Appearance: slightly hazy black, no head. Taste: medium sweet. Palate: salty flavours coming up quickly, alcohol, toasted malts, coffee liqueur. Overall: very extreme, interesting, yet nothing I would drink again. Bottle at the brewery, Ellon.

Bottle, Brewdog, Leicester. Dark brown with a thin head. Aromas are sticky toffee with smoked ham and Chinese five spice. Earthy with lemon, raisins and toasted malts. Very spicy booze with marzipan and brandy. Flavours are sweet, burnt toffee and raisins with alcohol and coriander burn. Thick on the palate with brandy and leafy hops. Smoky meatiness with honey and lemon. The opposite of a session beer but still surprisingly drinkable. Good.
Bottle. Brown color with no head. Malty aroma with a notes of cherries. Taste like no beer, more similar to some cherry liquor. Warming alcoholic finish.

Nip from bottle at DogTap. Pours dark brown. Nose is very strong and boozy, sweet chocolate, whisky, vanilla, oak. Taste is also strong, thick, liqueur like, toasted and burnt malts, chocolate, raisin. Beer of itsown style but I still rather take an IS or whisky or portwine.

Wow, nuclear is definitely a great description of this brew. Heavy malt flavor like a barely wine, but tastes similar to a port wine. very intense on the pallet, has a very thick consistency, I was thinking molasses. Definitely a sipper.

Part of my 2013 backlog, tried at the Strait and Narrow, Lincoln. Black colour with no head. Alcohol aroma, but i guess thats not a surprise. Flavour has Toasted malt, and chocolate, also vanilla, reminds me of a sherry. Thick heavy on the palate.

Bottle. Black pour, no head. Aroma is sweet dark fruits with notes of oak and plenty of booze. Flavor is super sweet and intense. Big time raisin and oak with whiskey notes. Abv is there and its very warming but not overwhelming. Pretty tasty brew actually but a small glass was plenty for me.
Darkred, no head, clear. Raisins, port and alcohol in the aroma. Rasins, burned taste with strong burned, liqruish alcoholic aftertaste

Poured an opaque black with a reddish brown edge tint - looks like an old port. Aroma with distinct sweet raisin/wine characters, old dried fruits and nice alcohol. Taste of sweet raisins, dark dried fruits, hint of coffee, hint of roasted grain; a peppery after-taste - a bit like a fortified wine. Heavy body. Smooth, dry, long spicy finish. Worth the try and the taste!

due to the multiple freezings it looks more like a dark barleywine than a stout. pours ruby tinged dark brown, no head. little carbonation, but its there. feel is nice, fairly smooth for the strength, but the aroma is all hot whiskey and sweet. no depth. Utopias had set the bar high for super strong ales as far as flavor and complexity go and this just didnt match up. flavor is nice, but got hot too as the beer warmed. lots of rasisiny sweetness and candi sugar, whiskey...not much in the way of stout character at all. overall, a cool experience. our ears were all toasty warm when we were done, but absolutely not worth the ridiculous price. at least SA got their abv through the brewing process and not by freezing the beer multiple times."

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2015 Oak aged imperial stout pumped to an ultra strong kind of stout liquor by means of the Eisbock method, like nearly all those super strong, liquor-like beers (if you can still call them that). No head due to the extreme alcohol strength, colour totally black. Exceedingly dense and powerful, if not overpowering, uncompromizing aroma of liquorice, peat, ashes, coffee liqueur, sherry, smoky single malt, bitter chocolate; candied fruits mark the onset, no carbonation, extremely dense and concentrated, very viscous and oily, very profoundly malty, woody, smoky, strong roasted bitterness like the strongest black coffee, all drenched in an explicit but elegant alcohol burn not unlike whisky or gin, very warming in the throat and very long. This thing will stick with you forever. Imperial stouts, because of their heavily concentrated character, lend themselves perfectly for this treatment - I liked this a lot more than their (even stronger) Sink the Bismarck, where the icing procedure was applied to IPA. Difficult to rate due to the relative lack of comparable beers, though, and still perhaps a bit over the top...

(BrewDog Tactical Nuclear Penguin) Bottle 375 ml at home, corked and caged, wrapped in a brown paper bag, with a penguin and 32% drawn on it, like it was done with a marker. Poured into a Borefts taster glass. Most expensive beer Ive bought till now.
Almost totally black, dark ruby shades when hold against the light. No head at all and even when I swirl the glass a bit, no lacing forms.
Lots of alcohol on the aroma, the first that hits the nose. Behind it aromas of vanilla, roasted malts, whiskey.
Intense alcohol burn that even made me cough a bit. Very sweet. Vanilla again, wood, whiskey, chocolate.
Full thick body, nice soft carbonation. Sticky on the palate.
Really great beer, fantastic sipper. If it wasnt that boozy it would be even better but hey, its 32% alc, Im not asking for miracles here.

Bottle Ive had sitting in the fridge, popped just over 8 months ago. An ounce or two poured into a snifter. Dark brownish black with no head. Aromas of big booze and spirits, dark fruit, sweet and candied notes. Tastes of peat, big booze and spirits, big smoke, dark fruit. Medium-light body with a dry and warm finish. Light oily mouthfeel, still carbonation. Interesting idea but a bit extreme, a few sips is really all you need ABV aside.
Big boy #3 at Craigs because hes sadistic. pours deep amber no head. nose is more whisky and not as sweet as other big brews. tastes pretty pungent of whisky, toffee, licorice, earth, and some smoke
Had one of these gems in Iceland on my stag, more for the novelty. A bit overbearing but drinkable.
Bottle at home. Pours black, very boozy, chocolate and coffee, sweet whisky, nice.

Bottle from my cellar consumed at Damicos. Pours black with no head. Nose is big boozy tones, black strap molasses, chocolate cake, grain alcohol. First sip is huge bitter sweet chocolate, burnt grain, smoke and coffe grinds. Finish is the best with a warming mulled wine flavors. Giant waste of money.

Wow, even huger than expected. More like a whiskey/eisbock but stout yeast. Pours dark unclear rich amber brown with no head and very little carbonation. Aroma brings sweet hot booze whiskey with sweet malts, caramel, and toffee. Flavor is like sweet whiskey with big alcohol notes on a balanced body for 32 ABV, syrupy but not took much.

Very different. Tried it two different Times'. Want a bottle at home. Give it to me

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sampled from a bottle, I couldnt drink a full bottle and this should be sold in a nip size. Very heavy roast and some smoke, which I like, but it is very thick and the roast so burnt that it is hard to drink. Really a few sips are enough.

Bottle at first "Er klopt iemand op de deur" tasting aka EBT3. Thx to everyone for sharing todays beers!
APPEARANCE: clear very dark beer, no foam.
NOSE: very sweet, too much alcohol.
TASTE: sticky, too much alcohol, alcohol burn.
Bottle 37,5 CL. Pours black with no head. Notes of salmiakki, chocolate, espresso, licorice. Well beer 32 alcohol not too much to say. Insane.- beerbasher

Sample from bottle. @ gråsälstasting #4. Big thanks Jookos! Batch #906. Black color, no head. Hint of vinegar, chocolate, greek spirits. Long dark fruity, sweet aroma. Surprisingly drinkable.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Shared a bottle with friends. Deep brown almost black pour with a nonexistent head. Powerful aroma, alcohol and vanilla. Tastes is coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla. Alcohol content is present throughout the whole experience. Definitely a sipper not a gulper.

This is a heavy thick beer, you can taste the whiskey flavors, more similar to a fine port, if i had the money I would drink it in a port glass or brandy balloon after every meal. Tasty, strong and warming.

From bottle #908. Wow, this is a huge beer, well its kind of a beer. Huge very complex aroma that hints at how intense the flavours will be, but it lies, this thing grab you by the throat. Pours and looks like a port, thick with no head. The alcohol is very warming, ultra rich flavours keep changing as you sip. Its not an everyday beer but I liked it a lot.

The aroma is so fantastic Im enjoying it with every sip. Very thick, tasty, and it definitely has a strong Scottish whiskey taste. Id love to have a small glass every day but unfortunately the price tag wont let me do this. Well done to the brew dog boys.

When I tasted it I wasnt so sure that its an ale. More like Irish Whiskey. Woody, smokey. Incredibly tough brew - more like Incredible HULK of the craft beer :D Warm feeling afterwards, more like hot.. licorice aftertaste.
Although when I get to know the price - I was shocked. Its way too expensive. But Im glad I tried it once.
I loved it but I still dont think that its an ale..

Appearance: Clear dark brown with no head.
Aroma: Whisky notes, port, spiritous, red wine, wood, treacle, berry fruit.
Taste: Medium sweetness, low sourness and low/medium bitterness.
Palate: Thick smooth texture, medium/heavy texture, no carbonation, lingering dry treacle, liquorice, spiritous, fruity finish with a lot of alcohol warmth and dryness. After the initial sweetness their is a slight bitter peat/ whisky note.
Comments: Lovely.

At Sfrangeways with will Taylor Matt and friends. Pours brown black with no carb or head. Aroma is very pungent malt syrup. Taste is harsh alcohol, covered by some sticky malt and hop resin, almost oil, malt oil, resin sticky soy sauce.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2014 small sample courtesy of a friend.
clear deep amber pour. No carbonation or head. Heavy alcohol. Lots of raisins. Pretty good

Pre-DLD bottle share in 2014. Pour is deep black with no head. Aroma is of strong alcohol, brown sugar, and tar. Flavor is very smoky with notes of burnt malt, chocolate, cigar smoke, and licorice. Tastes like scotch with some sugar added, better than I expected.
Had this in like at dark lord day. Massive to say the obvious. Vanilla and whiskey. Coffee beans. I liked it most others with me didnt

A very sweet beer that has a smooth finish. Has a hard alcohol finish and smells vanilla flavored. Had at dark lord day. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Birthday beer in The Macc, Macclesfield, Cheshire. Very dark brown with pretty much no head. Aroma of cough syrup, alcohol, sherry. Flavour is lots of warm alcohol,hint of chocolate and licorice, smokey lip burning finish. Good effort I suppose!

Bottle @ Oslo, Galway [160414] ... got a free sample of this at the bar! Thanks a million!
Dark brown, clear, no head
Aroma - Lots of booze, deep rich sweet dark malts, bit of solvent (prob the alcohol),
Taste - Alcohol, very thich rich dark sweet raisin malts, molasses, sweet dark chocolate, very rich dried fruit raisin malts.

My first sip brings no relief from the torturous aroma. Its a mouthful of ashtrays alongside relentless, burning alcohol. To replicate the taste of TNP, place a burnt chunk of wood in the center of a large mixing bowl. Using water, rinse out a few dozen heavily-soiled ashtrays into the bowl. Add rotting forest foliage, pure ethanol, a bottle of whiskey, liquified peat moss, and unrefined petroleum. Give the concoction a brisk stir, take a sip, then puke your brains out. Voila: Homemade Tactical Nuclear Penguin!

Nip at Brew Dog Camden - 21/12/12.
Dark mahogony brown with no head, still akin to a fine port or whisky.
Nose is big on booze, cherry, berry fruits, dark sugars, wood, spirits, aniseed, booze over rides and wins the day!
Taste follows the nose, sherry like flavours, sweet sugars, smoke, boozey, rich and complex.
Full bodied + , cloying, sweet boozey finish.
Very drinkable in a small dose, not sure about the imperial stout listing, more akin to barley wine.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle. Nose pleasant, of alcohol, hops and dried fruits. Tastes rich and full. Lots of alcohol and dried fruits. Sweet and hoppy finish.

25ml served from cooled bottle at BrewDog, Manchester (7.Jul.2012)
Clear cognac/ruby coloured body, no head or lacing. Smells like dusty port and moist cellar. The alcohol is quite noticeable, but also charcoal, dark fruit, cherry and a hint of raspberry. Wine, more than beer, so I probably wouldnt buy it again. Its smooth for its strength though!

25 ml bottle sample @ Brewdog Camden. This beer is actually shockingly popular due to many gents ordering from time to time the most expensive beer on the menu or due to the allure of the very high alcohol. Even at the time I was @ Brewdog Camden - I heard people talking about it, people showing interest and people ordering it. The bartender showed zero surprise when I got it. I know that these days it is just made from the failed batches of every dark beer Brewdog eisboked and that it costs them 1 £ to make. I simply needed to know... I was a willing victim. Unsurprisingly this was completely stil, dark brown, very dark bordeaux red with huge legs. Smell is dominated by booze but oddly this is rather enjoyable, getting some syrup and liquorice as well, extremely thick dark fruits. Taste is very sweet, gluhwine like, a bit like that very sweet Canadian wine thing, I recently tasted, syrup, syrup de Liege, super concentrated dark sugarm crazy amounts of syrup, abhorn syrup,  liquorice, toffee, soy sauce light hint, very sticky, very sweet, plenty of cough syrup, sticky. This stuff sticks to the inside of the glass, I was prepared for the worst but this turned out quite lovely honestly - huge surprise.

Bottle shared by djmiller92. Thanks Dave.

The beer is chestnut brown. No head or lace. The aroma brings alcohol, smoke, cracked pepper, peat. Reminiscent of scotch in some regards. The flavor offers syrup, candy, malt, peppers, dark fruits, booze, scotch, plums, raisins. Whoa. The feel is a bit like cough syrup. Coats the palate. Lingering alcohol and syrup in the finish. A 2 oz. pour is sufficient. I enjoyed the experience. This is a beer I have wanted to taste since I first heard of it. Bold, unique, and worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-17-2011

Clean brown body, no head and watery body. Rich aroma, malts going liquor, alcohol, raisins. Drinkable body, astringent dark hops, sharp notes. Not as bad as expected. Warming. Interesting experiment. Thanks to Vaisha! (UDRBM)

Bottle, batch 3, 11/12/2012. Pours black, slightest of heads, quickly almost flat in appearance. Aroma of chocolate fudge with dark brown sugar, sweet coffee licorice, candied fruits, vanilla and wood, moderately boozy character (so not as bad as expected). Taste is candied licorice, salty chocolate, intense charred bitterness and booze. Thick body, long hot finish. Interesting, but hard to drink this one.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2013 Bottle @ NK Saluhall. Served together with a smoked reindeer heart that went surprisingly well with it. Dark brown, almost black colour with a tan head. Aroma is alcohol, dark fruit, raisins. Flavour is dark fruit, raisin, chocolate, alcohol, caramel.


-Rated 11/8/2012 - 7/4/9/4/16
Sample from bottle @ Bull & Bear Inn. Tasted alongside Sink the Bismarck. Dark brown colour with no head. Alcohol-filled aroma. Aroma isnt as pleasant as Sink the Bismarck, but the flavour is so much better. Full bodied, sweet dried fruit with vanilla and of course alcohol.

Bottle. Opaque black, very viscous liquid with minimal tan head. Aroma of soy, booze, raw sugar, raisins, dark fruit, licorice, booze, wood and vanilla. Taste is heavy sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of licorice, raw sugar, chocolate and booze. Full bodied with no carbonation. Nice.

Obviously strong but should be enjoyed as a liquor. I've wondered what a whiskey made with hops would taste like, now I know. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sampled from a 0.33l bottle @ BrewDog - Camden. No head, a blurry deep deep copper body. Smells absofruitely fantastic. Lots and lots of smoke and wood. Sweet really concentrated caramel with red raisins and dates. My god it smells a lot , and I really really like it! It has no carbonation, and its so sticky as sticky gets in texture. Sweet, dark, bready, and just extremely caramelly. My, oh my! This was really something. Dates, dried red apples, smoke, wood and tons of whisky-sherry. Sweet and a true delightful to try., 22.07.2012

Shot from a bottle at Birmingham Beer Festival 2012. Super sweet, strong and tart. Extremely smooth, with a finish that goes on and on and on and on. Thought this would be dreadful, but its pretty good. Its big. Bish and Gurd are here now, after having been trapped outside.
Drunk at Birmingham Beer Festival. Thought far more of this than I expected. Really easy drinking I thought for what it is. Tasted like a stout. Odd but good.

Bottle shared with friends. Dark reddish colour, no head. Aroma of glue, peat and booze... loads of booze. Flavour is intense sweet, again a lot of alcohol and a big alcoholic burning mouthfeel. I can appreciate this, but Ive had much better.

Shot (yes) at Birmingham Beer Festival 2012.  Difficult to rate when it is served as a shot.  Not that Id want any more... Warming like a spirit.  Because it is?  Dark thing.  Head?  In a shot glass?  No.  Forget the lacing as there is no room.  Long bitter aftertaste but still drinkable (sipable) somehow.  I think I like it but I cant say why.

Stirchley Wines Bottle shop at Brum Beer Fest 2012; Sticky syrupy brown pour, some dried fruit in the taste, I could taste a tiny bit of malt. But the alcohol level was overwhelming struggled to finish a shot measure off.  One to tick off but will not be going back for more.

Sticky aromas of alcohol, caramel, oak, fudgy
Wow! Boom! Alcohol, oily, shit loads of caramel, cherries, intense inyense sweetness!

Bottle from beer temple, Amsterdam. Black in the glass, no head. Smells insanely complex, can def smell licorce and the alcohol. Taste of smoke, alcohol, chocolate, licorice. Insanely sweet. I love the beer, but all the different tastes makes it difficult to tell what?s what. (Atleast for a beginner).

Thanks (I think) to danielnovak3 for the share. Served in a mini taster snifter.

A: The pour is completely still with no head. It has the appearance of dark rum.

S: Ash trays, permanent marker, hard liquor and dark fruits. Simply stunning.

T: The taste is burning wood, embers, ash tray, hard liquor, burnt hair and salty leather.

M: Thin, extremely hot and down right horrible.

O: This now hold the distinction of the worst beer Ive ever had. This is a complete gimmick and should never be brewed again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-25-2012

The most beautiful beer Ive ever tasted. Rich, sweet, strong, dark.. I dont care if its expensive,  I love it. I first tried this last January out of the bottle. I couldnt believe how great it was.. my taste buds exploded in excitement!
Bottled. Poured dark brown in color with no head. Sweet, portvine like aromas mostly, perhaps some dark fruits also. Sweet in flavour also, portvine still, perhaps some cough medicine too.
At brewdog camden. Dark copper color with no head. Aroma of alcohol and salmiak. Strong taste of licorice, some coffee also. Strong, thick and different .

Bottle. Pours dark honey/caramel brown - like treacle - with no head at all to be mustered. Nose is whisky, stinging the nose with alcohol a little, some dark chocolate, some wood. Theres a hop playing about in there too, spruce. Very toasty. Some vanilla. A small sip and the mouthfeel is a little cloying and sticky. Taste is a little licorice, then a large swathe of whisky, then a cooling vanilla (ice-cream) note and then a final sting of alcohol and cough syrupyness. Play with it a bit and you can dig out some caramel, a little chocolate, toast and smoke. Its fascinating, but I struggle to call this a beer. Sippable and one you have to respect before diving headfirst.

Bottle, shared at RBAG Summer Session 2012. Fairly innocuous looking auburn pour, absolutely still, no head. The aroma is that of a car accident, literally: burnt rubber, hot asphalt, petroleum. This is the nastiest smelling brew Ive ever inhaled. It actually burns the nostrils, and not in a funny Sex Panther Anchorman way. Flavour is stunningly bitter and harshly tannic. Like chewing on dyed leather. There are sherry-ish undertones here, but man, you really have to search to get past the harshness. Brutal. Im at a loss on how to score this, as it is such an innovation that I want to give at least some kudos, but as a beverage of pleasure it fails completely. To quote Ralph Wiggam : "It tastes like burning!!!!"
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Sample during tasting @ Ölrepubliken. Pours dark reddish brown, almost black, with no head worth mentioning. Smell is very sweet with alcohol, roasted malts, caramelized nuts, caramel, sweet liquorice candy, coffee candy and resinous wood. Taste is extremely sweet and bitter with roasted malts, peat, alcohol, salty liquorice, soy sauce, resinous wood and moist soil. Mouthfeel is extremely boozy and medium to ful, bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with alcohol, roasted malts, lemon zest, wood, grass, ammonium chloride and soy sauce. Very over the top.

2 ounce pour.  Black, no head.  Aroma of old school black permanent marker and booze.  Taste is how the black marker smells and booze.  I thought the bottle looked cool, and it was fun to try this beer.  This was not tasty and Im glad I didnt buy the bottle.

RBAG Summer Session 2012. Dark brown with a hint of red like maybe dirty, bloody water. Ash, tobacco, sin and lost dreams. Thats the aroma in a nutshell. Tastes like some kind of monster spirit made up in a laboratory out of parts of lesser spirits. Super sticky and full of booze. Not my thing - but actually better than I was expecting. Glad I tried it - wont be trying it again.
4 cl from a previously opened bottle. Strong aroma of alcohol, cherry and raisin. Flavors are cherry and plum. Sweet and sour finish of warm alcohol.

2011 production, thanks to a friend from England for bringing this to me rather than buying in Australia, saving about $120 in the process.  Pours clear dark mahogany with no head, and leaves some wonderful slightly tan legs.  Aromas of roasted malt, toffee, caramel, vegemite, dark sherry or port, a little peat, smoke and sea salt.  Quite sweet, with the alcohol cutting through, leading to vegemite, roasted malt and a mild burnt bitterness.  Full bodied, as you might expect, no carbonation at all, quite slick with a long-lived warmth from the alcohol and a little bitterness.  Despite the surprise your brain gets when it encounters the roast and burnt bitterness this is really enjoyable.

Pour is deep drown mahogany to black no head at all. Aroma is earthy and very heavy on fermented dark fruits and nuts. Fingers the glass like aged sherry or red wine. Very cool beer but not for a none liquor drinker. Full flavored and musty very much like thomas hardy ale. Would drink again but not likely to buy again.

09/12 A 0.33 l from Slovenian outlet, bottle shared with Marko and ogivlado. It poured very dark reddish to black body with tiny head. Poured clear deep red with a red wine look, ruby hue, no head and hardly any carbonation .... aroma was strong and of smoked peat malts and lightly herbal with notes of berries, light caramel, roasted and some wood .... taste is of smoked peat malts, berries, caramel, lightly roasted and wood with whiskey aspects as well  ... powerful stuff mouthfeel is hot and very syrupy and thick ..... finishes with a ton of heat and abv and a lingering smokey bitter punch

[bottle at Danish invasion tasting--thanks cgarvieuk!]
Quite ethanolic aroma that is brandy-like and with some rice wine/sake accent. Thick, dark amber with no head. Slightly rancid brandy flavour with some vanilla and butterscotch and a nutty sake-like finish. Fully body, low carbonation, warming.

Backlog nov/dec 2010, on bottle at Dr.Jekyll.
Dark golden.
Full body & complexity.
Interesting and ok
Smell of nuts and coffee. Surprisingly carbonated considering the strength. Heavy alcoholic aroma and extreme sweetness. Aftertaste of salmiac and overripe berries. Oily.

Small pour split with hudsonphotog at The Meddlesome Moth.

The beer pours a clear brown color with absolutely no head. The aroma is very smokey with a lot of alcohol, dark fruit and a hint of toffee. The flavor is more of the same. The alcohol really stands out as expected, but there is also a big peat smoke character as well as some roasted malt, chocolate and some more dark fruit. Medium mouthfeel and no carbonation. You can really get the Scotch-barrel aged notes in the beer, which I think is OK, but not really my thing. A decent beer, but not as good as Sink the Bismarck.

Sample @ Beer Temple, Amsterdam. This bomb pours a nice brown, with no head whatsoever. Aroma is, not surprisingly, alcohol, but also dark fruits, prunes and raisins. Full, very oily body, and of course no carbonation. Behind all the alcohol theres a quite complex flavour of chocolate, caramel, dark fruits and burned malts. The rather sweet finish sticks for quite a while.

29th December 2009ChrisO Night Of The Gaylords tasting. Clear brown beer. Palate is light and dry. Boozy nose but also malty. Hot malt with a large dose of spirity heat and licorice spice. A little glue in there as well. Pretty spicy malt! Hard to rate. I preferred the Schorschbock 31.
bottle thanks awesome steve. this beer fucking sucks it taste like like a goddamn burning forest

Had the last ounce for a bottle previously opened at Brew Dog Camden. Paid 6 Quid for a pour and shared with a friend.

A - Dark caramel brown. Huge alcohol legs. No head.

S - Smells caramel whiskey. Slight. Oak brown sugar

T - Holy crap. So boozy it burns my chest. Sweet like candy corn or caramel. Aftertaste is like burnt wood terrible burnt vanilla pretty bad

M - Slick and oily. Heavy body. Horrible after taste

O  60/100. Disappointed that I have two bottles of this at home unopened. Its really a bad beer and not worth drinking. Insanely heavy and high alcohol and tastes like it was once a beer with a lot of added syrup.

Bottle from the BrewDog website. Very dark brown-black coloured with ruby red highlights. This is an extremely strong powerful warming, almost burning beer! It has an oily mouthfeel with an intial hit of alcohol followed by burnt caramel, molases, liquorice, chocolate, leather and roasted notes with more warmth, burning and smoke on the finish. This is the most powerfully flavoured beer I have ever sampled. Whisky like and When mixed with a dash of water, the burning is removed and the mouthfeel is smoothed.

 Nose is very alcoholic like caramel and wood too,nose is very powerful.
. Aroma is like a liqueur with toffe dry grapes, fig, caramel, an extreme long aftertaste. One of the most tasty and pure ber i had, amasing aftertaste.
