UPDATED: JUN 17, 2012 From the 5/2012 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz green bottle this beer poured a black color with a trace soapy tan head that faded quickly and left no lacing. The aroma was soy sauce, cream sherry and ripe dark fruits. The flavor was hot and boozy with notes of soy sauce, cream sherry, wood, port wine and more booze. The finish was long with soy sauce, sherry and wood lingering. Very boozy. Drinkability is very low. It is a chore to get through even a bit.

Bottle, several times, but first serious rating. Pitch black oily pour. Heavily smoked and burnt, whisky, barrel condition, light peating. Mouth is alcohol, spirit burn, sweet, cognac, sweet and cloying, then cleaning and alcohol spirit burn. Back of the throat burn too. Interesting trial, but not sure it could be an enjoyable sip-able beer-spirit.

Bottle on more occasions than I wish to remember. It pours very dark brown, with no head. The nose is alcohol, particularly whisky notes, toffee ice cream, rich coffee, roasted malt, caramel, cocoa, tar and liquorice. The taste is roasted malt, coffee, treacle, tar, liquorice, smoke, alcohol, chocolate, oak, vanilla, dark fruit, caramel, toffee and brown sugar, with a long, very boozy finish. Full body, low/no carbonation and oily mouth-feel. Theres no denying that its breaking boundaries. Good as a night cap. I have enjoyed this quite a bit in the past, but I find it inconsistent of late making me question the consistency of the base beer. A fun beer nonetheless.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks Tomer G. Very dark brown, opaque, no head. Tear-inducing aroma, tar, miso. Sweet taste, then salty, very alcoholic but theres chocolate somewhere. Weirdly amazing. Smooth and oily texture, very mild carbonation.

Bottle at craigs. Clear dark brown, no head, flat. Aromas not bad, chocolate and ovaltine come through, not a huge alcohol whiff. Similar taste, toffee, chocolate and ovaltine. Not nearly as bad as I had anticipated

Bottle:
A pitch black beer with no head.
Smell is a lovely mix of soya and molasses with some roasted sticky/sweet barley malts, spices and a hint of iron.
Taste is spicy, sticky, roasted barley malts, molasses, liquorice, full syrup, coffee, thick, well balanced though a bit on the spicy side. Guess the barrel aging was noticeable, but very well mixed and mellowed in with this beer.
Spicy liquorice sticky coffee aftertaste.
No carbo, soft thick oily mouthfeel, full body and an oily texture.
Like an alcoholic version of a spicy apple syrup.
You could taste the alcohol, still well hidden. I liked it, even with this idiotic alcohol percentage.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks Tomer G. Murky dark brown color with no head. Aroma of lots of alcohol, some canned plums and some weird olive notes. Flavor of chocolate, lots and lots of alcohol, some wood and a bit of fruitiness. Really full syrupy body. Pretty nice but a bit tough to drink (duh...)

25cl from bottle at Brewdog Camden, London. Pours a deep ruby brown color with no head or bubbles. Aroma is sweet: caramel, toffee, alcohol. Taste ius similar: caramel, toffee, booze, figs and plums. No carbonation, thick oily body. Overall, very interesting as a liquor and enjoyable in small quantities. Definitely odd and off-putting as a beer. How to rate it? Hedonistically, I have to say I loved the drink and the experience, just dont expect a beer.

Worth a try for the interesting oiliness and spirit measure strength, nightcap perhaps. But not appealing enough after that, too much liquorice, too much like old cough medicine. Sorry lads, hats off for the effort although it is also way too expensive. Would rather spend its 35 pound tag on a decent single malt from Scotland instead!
user_location: Brighton and Hove, East Sussex, ENGLAND

text: Pungent almost savoury flavour. Deep brown liquid that sticks to the side of the glass. Flavour is almost overwhelming cough-syrupy with little hint of its Paradox origins. Something Im glad I tried once, but it is the only Brewdog Ive had that has felt genuinely gimmicky.

Bottle with Sean and Pat. Finally decided to grab a bottle of the infamous Tactical Nuclear Penguin. This is one of the most well known beers in the craft beer community due to its 32% alcohol content which was achieved through freezing the beer for two weeks and aging it in multiple casks. This was the strongest beer in the world for a decent bit of time until another company beat out brewdog, causing them to outdue themselves again with Sink the Bismark. Stay tuned for that review in the near future. Penguin pours a dark brown color with no head or lacing at all. Aroma burns the nostrils and releases fragrances of mead, belgian quad, cognac, smokey tar, whiskey, licorice. Taste is burnt almonds, and cognac tasting heat. I mean this beer is barely drinkable being this hot and full of spicy booze. This beer was purely a novelty and should not be considered beer in my opinion. Still gets you heavily mangled and comes with a cool brown bag and hand drawn penguin from the brewer. Worth trying

Strong ass beer. That's all I have to say. Good draw and texture.  Color was dark but not a stout taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black without foam.
Is it a beer?
It smells like a Banyuls or a Maury: dried plum, cherries in alcohol.
It taste like a peaty scotch and fortified wine with cinnamon and cloves.
So no, its not a beer.
Aromas in nose and mouth are blended: coffee, liquorice root, orange peel, nuts, slinity ...
Very, very powerful and alcoholic sensation.
Wow !
Sampled @ Beer Temple, Amsterdam. Amber-brown color, no head. Smell pure alcohol and ethanol. Taste alcohol, apple, syrup and sweetness. Way too strong, taste is overwhelmed by alcohol.

Bottled bought in Amsterdam. I really expected more, but wait until my 1000 rated beer to try it, was kinda frustrating. Very Dark rubi color with no head! aroma is complex but the alcohol can be smelled from distance. Hints of dark fruits like plum, caramel and roasted malt. Flavor is like a strong liquor. too much alcohol!! after alcohol I could feel something like coffee and roasted malt, ending with some sweetness. but the beginning is like whisky or vodka. mouthfeel is pour alcohol... Do not worth all that money and thanks god I bought it in Amsterdam, because in Brazil would cost me around US$ 300.00!
En botella.Color cobre viejo.Aromas a madera,resina,alcohol....En boca es compleja y calurosa.Interesante,pero para beber muy de vez en cuando.

This needs a bit more respect than it gets here.  Yes it is gimmicky at 32%, but drank as a brandy-replacement, this beer works well.  Huge alcohol and dried-fruit nose and long lasting bitter taste.  Pours light.
Amber brown colour with no head. Smells alcohol, glue, resin and peat. Tastes sweet, malty, caramel, nuts, honey and (Dutch:)Rinse Appelstroop. Warming, full body, thick and very little carbo.

4 cl sample from 33 cl bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu. Rated on 08.04.2011
Aroma has very aggressive notes of varnish remover and plastic glue  feels like Mikkeller Black in the power of three. I cannot even smell this like I usually smell beer. Flavour is strong on alcohol with varnish remover, plastic glue, very salty licorice and expectorant. Lots of stinging alcohol on palate. This is rather hard to rate as a beer.

25ml measure, Interval Cafe, Sheffield. Slightly pink brown hue, aroma of astringent resin, whiskey and rum. A sweetness, lots of vegetable and spruce. Alcohol is present but not overpowering. Finished long and resinous, with the alcohol building and lingering through the end.

4cl glass at Amundsen
When does a beer end being a beer? Not at 32% obviously. 
Dark brown color, looks a bit like thin coffee, no head of course. 
The aroma is obviously not free for alcohol, that is joined by coffee, oak and malts. Lots of them.
Taste is very good for being this strong, can sense some smoke, again rich malts, and sweetness. Alcohol is pretty good hidden in the taste.

Black pour. No head. No lacing. Leaves an oily looking coating on the glass like Scotch. Holy boozy nose Batman. Smells of whiskey. Tastes like distilled Scotch ale. Burns the mouth and throat, but has a very pleasant sweetness. Coats the mouth well. Very good. Very surprised that it is this good actually.

Csak a jó sör, Budapest.
Olyan színe van, mint egy sűrű kávélikőrnek és az állaga is hasonló, úgy folyik mint egy motorolaj. Habja nincs, azt ne is keressük. Illata olyan, mint egy erős Madeira likőrbornak, amibe aszalt gyümölcsöket áztattak, egy kis pörkölt malátát szórtak. Íze olyan, mint egy amontillado sherrynek, amibe a szokásosnál több brandyt töltöttek, aszalt gyümölcsöket daraboltak és még egy kis Cavendish pipadohányt is érezni benne. Sűrű teste van és alig érezni benne buborékot. Utóíze keserédes, likőrös és ebben érezni egy csipetnyi komlót is. Finom és érdekes, de ez már nem igen hasonlít igazi sörhöz, de egyszer ezt is meg kellett kóstolni és ezt nem bántam meg!

Bottle. From November 2011 notes. Wood/oak aroma, brandy like grape aroma. Clear brown with no head. Flavor was fusel, earthy, cherry cough medicine, with a bitter finish.Full bodied with a full alcohol burn. Interesting novelty, but way too hyped and expensive for what it is.
Dark, dark brown with of course no head. Massive legs as it is swirled in the glass. Wonderful nose that had me wanting to just sit and smell. Amazingly smooth considering the abv.

This one needs some time. Big, Boozy, lots of whiskey and coffee aromas. Too hot to really enjoy, but I suppose thats kind of the point. I bought 2 so I think Ill give the other one a year or two to mellow out. Surprisingly complex flavor profile, but it unfortunately takes a backseat to the heat.

Smells of marmitey hop whiskey (if it existed) - variously sweet, savoury, and alcoholic. Sits flat and angry in the glass; looks like wood varnish, a deep mahogany fluid that has no head, no carbonation, just a glorious ruby tint. Flavours of burnt toffee, wood, alcohol burn, alcohol, alcohol burn, and some alcohol. Imagine a hopped whiskey, make it slightly better than youd imagine, then you have this.

I stood there at first with my nose stuck in the glass.  Its a really nice nose.  Of course its boozy as hell.  Mixture of Whiskey, Vanilla, Caramel, and Oak.   Its smokey and woody.  I thought the smell was really well done here.  Then I got to the taste. 

Like I said above, I was not quite ready.  The burn on this one is huge and it got stuck in my throat.  I almost lost my first full sip on the floor but luckily as Mom always told me Dont chew with your mouth open I just couldnt believe the hotness on this one.   It was like sucking down moonshine.  But the next few sips were just fine as I ready for the barrage of hotness.  The taste of course is full of that alcohol burn but more flavors seem to somehow come through.  Charred oak, toffee, roasted malt, and caramel.  Theres a certain sweetness to the beer but its overshadowed by the alcohol and the smokey and sometimes charred wood effect. 

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and a tad bit syrupy.  Theres no carbonation and no head.  Its pretty much a dead beer.  I enjoyed it at room temperature and I believe its the only way to actually enjoy it.  You would lose a lot of the flavor if you took this baby out of the fridge and had it.  Honestly if you get a bottle, treat it like Utopias.  Dont put it in the fridge.  Leave it out and enjoy it.
smoky, flat, really intense and warming. Blackish colour and a long finish,

Brown. Black? Smells like apples and booze. And gasoline. Flat. Taste is apples and booze. Oak?

Well, now I can say Ive had that one.

Bought a 375ml bottle with 3 of my friends. Went in it expecting nothing special, mainly it it for the experience. But i was pleasantly surprised. Cracked this with no pop as the cork came out. Poured into 4 small shot sized snifters. Forced a head on it that disappeared within seconds. Deep dark brown but translucent similar to a dark whiskey. Smelled of deep figs, roast and a little boozy. This is were i was surprised the most. actually expecting to retain zero qualities of beer but instead though it tasted of sweet liquor with a nice chocolate roast at the end "just enough to realize it was still a beer". Piney hops barely noticeable but there seemed to help dry out the beers taste and counteract the sweetness. Oaky taste on the sides of the tongue as well. I feel if your a fan of liquor as well as beer you could appreciate the finer qualities in this beer. Defiantly not worth the price tag, but overall glad i got to enjoy this.
Pours dark brown amber no head. Aroma us BW lke, hoppy, fruity, malty and sweet. Flavor similar to aroma, bitter and a bit too boozy. Finishes. Bitter,malty and fruity..

Shared bottle thanks to my beer pal Kim. Pours pitch black with no head at all.
Aroma is aceton and shoepolish, nothing good in my world. Taste is strong soy sauce, heavy burning alcohol,extreme in all ways, except drinkability. Never again. King is undressed.

Bottled 375ml. -Online from BrewDog - Batch 19.  Poured dark, no head. Very strong smells, especially alcohol and hints of port wine - took breath away a little. Sniffed for ages before finally taking tastes which imparted smokey molasses taste with again a rum cask port wine flavour - could have tricked someone that they were drinking a strong port instead of beer.  The warmer the beer got it mellowed into nice sipper.  I was having Penguin not expecting a great deal from the teste but having it mainly for the sake of saying I had tasted one - but it was also a nice beer and I appreciated the experience.  (This was 1 of 28 different BrewDog beers my son and I consumed over past week - all but one great)

Bottled 375ml. -from Slovenian BrewDog outlet in Koper. Batch No. 012 Amber/brown coloured, no head at all. Im so sure about the nose. Wood, alcohol and smoke which are partially nice but also partially repulsive. Strong roasted malt, dark chocolate and tar with burning alcohol. Intensive and long-lasting smokey alcoholic finish and aftertaste. Like this one.

Thanks to my good friend Jon Montgomery for pouring me a couple of ounces from his bottle! Tasted on 12/28/2011. Colour: Very dark brown with dark low but firm head. Nose: Lots of dark fruits...candied figs, blackberries, prunes. Whisps of peated smoke, motor oil, burnt caramel and old oak. Taste: Medium sweet, medium bitter, medium sour. The 32% is well hidden in the layers of oak and heavy salted butter. Toffee plays about.... mid palate brings out some honeyed fruits and then whisky arrives late and is wrapped in a solid bitterness. I was pleasently surprised by this stuff and the 2 ounces I did drink was enough to give it a fair judgement. Well done BrewDog.

Wow....very interesting beer. Aroma is full of scotch notes. It is actually hard to get past the alcohol on the nose but it is easy to smell all of the roasted malts. The appearance is a brown/red color that leaves huge alcohol legs on the glass. Taste is very interesting. I was actually surprised that there is some carbonation in this beer. The taste is full of roasted malt notes with some nice raisin flavors coming through. Has a very Sherry like mouthfeel. The aftertaste is a bit tough on the palate, but for a beer of this size (32%) it sips well, albeit slowly.

Dark reddish amber with no head. Pours very oily. with little bits of oak sediment. Strong alcohol, like a spirit smell. Smoke, raisin, dark malt, vinegar and almost a fruity peach nose. Medium oily flat body. Taste is stronger than tequilla. Very hard bitter whiskey wood alcohol taste with some caramel, malt, and ash. Not for drinking only burning sipping. Very intense for a drink. Leaves a warm rumble in my stomach. Will take my time to finish this bottle.

OMG ... I cant believe all the low ratings on this one.  330ml bottle which came with a rubber stopper poured 50ml at a time over 6 days into a snifter reddish black in color with almost no head or lacing.  Aroma is huge roasted malts with smoked peat and alcohol.  Taste is big malty sweetness with whiskey and smoked peat with a big alcohol burn.  This is NOT a bottle to be drank in one sitting, as it is very heavily bodied with little to no carbonation and with the huge alcohol should be sipped more like a fine scotch.  I gave my buddy the remaining 30ml and he thought it was good as did I.

Bottle thanks to Wes. Rating #284. Thick black darkness, very still and just a wisp of a head. Big soy sauce aroma, concentrated dark fruits, just huge. Flavor is huge alcohol and a big peaty smokiness, tongue coating blackness and a alcohol burn all the way down. (2055)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Batch 12, Croatian RB Crew. Daaark red-amber body. No head. Nose, chocolatey alcohol, raisins. Aaand thats it for te nose. Soy sauce, roasted chocolate, salty. Cabbage. Wha? Warming alcohol. Erm... Bitterish. Overall, interesting. Nothing more.

I had this 5 weeks ago. I can still taste it. I have a small glass sitting 7 feet away from me. I can smell it from here. Im trying to drink another beer right now, so I cant actually drink this while I m rating it, Im going to have to do it from memory. Problem is, my brain was so traumatized, Im having to dig deep here to get past the PTSD that was drinking this beer. Dark brown with a hint of red like maybe bloody dirt water. Ash, tobacco, sin and lost dreams. Thats the aroma in a nutshell. The taste is like Earth might taste after the Machines take over, and is much like the smell. God forbid we ever go through an actual attack if it feels anything like this. Super sticky and full of booze. Kind of like senior prom. Honestly, I think Ive lost my ability to reproduce.
Color oscuro caoba con poca espuma.aromas alcoholicos ahumados y madera.sabor intenso con notas a coñac y porto.curiosa!
Just an absolutely dreadful beer and certainly not an imperial stout. Brutal rotten pear and ugly molasses. Just bad. Hardly even worth the tick.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a tiny head. Quite a bit of alcohol in the aroma with notes of malt, liquorice and raisins. Alcohol, sweet malt, liquorice, apples and raisins in the flavour.

Aroma of spirits. Some caramel, som lactose and brown sugar. Maubere a little bit of wood? Maybe something else. Its hard to tell, due to All the alcohol. 
  Really like the Bismarck better, and am really into the concept.

Tepid nut brown. Head? Ha. Starchy apple skin, brown sugar nose, all under alcohol whack. Oily body, no carbonation, apple and root at front, ash and prune mid with more brown sugar and oxidation through the hot finish, probably would have tasted better out of an old cardboard box.

Bouteille partagée par Georgebrassin. Bière foncée avec des reflets rougeâtres et aucune mousse. Effervescence minimale.  Rien ny est subtile. Au nez, des arômes très prononcés de scotch, de bois, de tourbe fumée et dalcool. On sent également les malts torréfiés et le café. En bouche, le scotch est on ne peut plus dominant, jai limpression de mâcher un copeau de bois provenant de baril de Lagavulin. Cest beaucoup trop pour moi. La fumée de tourbe, le bois et lalcool sont si présents quon ne perçoit pas tellement les subtilités de la "bière" proprement dite. Une expérience à vivre, mais à très petite dose et certainement pas au prix démesuré auquel elle est vendue! La bière est très liquoreuse comme on pourrait sy attendre.
Nose is super syrupy, ash, booze, grain alcohol.  Flavor is similar.  I need 75 characters.  damn.
Port and fusel nose with lots of oxidation. Taste is very sweet, boozy, with sherry and port,  burning hot finish.
Dark and nasty. The taste...let me just say I thought it tasted like something one might scrape off the bottom of their shoe after walking through a Scottish sheep pasture.

Bottle shared by maniac.  Pours clear brown with no head but nice legs.  Aroma is heavy caramel and cookie malt, heavy booze, light oak, and dark fruits.  Flavor is oxidized brandy from a used ash tray.  Full body, high warmth, and no carbonation.

330mL thanks to maniac. Pours a deep amber brown with some serious legs. Really nice legs. Nose is super umami, soy, nori, red rice starch, Chinese huangjiu rice wine, brown sugar clumps, but a little headache inducing with old red apple skins. Taste is pretty neutral moving to straight cigarette ash and gritty dirt. Perhaps gasoline. But mostly old cigarette ash. Ick. Almost beer characters remain. Feels surprisingly thin. One sip and I feel completely drunk. Ehhhh....gross.
Interesting curiosity. Taste is more "beer-like" than i suggested. Raw aroma.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2015 Bottle.  Wood, brandy and toffee malt aroma.  Dark brown color with no head.  Sweet toffee malt and cherry flavor that is quickly overwhelmed by the strong alcohol flavor.  Lingering bitterness.  Interesting but as rough as youd expect.

Bottle shared by maniac and Butters at the 16th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering, 11/5/11. Pours a clear dark brown color with no head. Huge booze notes in the aroma. Notes of rubbing alcohol, toffee and whisky. The taste is intense roasted malts, rubbing alcohol, grain, raisins and earthy notes. Full bodied. Extremely hot, harsh and astringent. This was not enjoyable... at all.

Holy shit. these fumes just about bowled me over. Like celery and scotch.  Got this for joes graduation, and hopefully this is no indication as to what the future holds for him.  While this is very interesting, it is very harsh. Uber hot. Tastes better than it smells. Very similar to a liquor. But very VERY harsh. Nailpolish. But I do appreciate the novelty.
Bottle. Dark and syrupy. Smells like astringent and earth, toffee and coffee. I like the bitter but the medicinal conflicts. Thanks to the sweet sixteen crew for sharing!

Auction winner.

Deep brown pour with hints of red. Aromas of coffee, earth, smoke, maple syrup, roasted malts and molasses.  A brew that warms the chest like cough medicine. A bold maple, dark fruit and coffee taste with some wood and some odd taste that I cant pin point. Odd.

Ive had this on a couple of occasions, but never really sat down to review this, until now.
This pours a thick black with the viscosity of motor oil only darker. A vigorous pour produced hints of a head that disappeared almost instantly. Smells of roast and chocolate a little bit, but really this is an overwhelming scotch and peat bomb. Lots of higher alcohol and that smoky peaty aroma that you get from a scotch is amplified from the freezing process. The taste does have some stout attributes, roast, caramel and fruit, but those are buried deep beneath the onslaught of smoked peat moss. Thick body, light level of carbonation, burning sweet smokey mouthfeel. In small quantities this is a fine nightcap, albeit a bit rough. Im glad I got to try this, but wouldnt seek it out again.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2012 Despite the very strong alcohol nose, I found this beer fairly palatable in small quantities, which is its intended use. Not the worst thing I have ever had, but definitely a beer suited for shock value. Price included. Nice undertones of molasses, but that is almost  it. Fun to say I have tried, but most likely will never again.
Lots of tar, chocolate and salt. Salty licorice with some sherry notes. Quite nice, some apples are in it too. Lots of molasses.

Bottle from Cavie.  Dark pour with little to no head.  Aroma is pancake syrup, alcohol, alcohol, brandy, and alcohol.  Taste is alcohol, coffee, molasses, licorice, alcohol, cinnamon, elephant tranquilizer, and alcohol.

Someone at the tasting suggested "It tastes like yuck."  

I think she was being overly generous.

Wallpaper paste and overripe apples with burnt dark rum.  Overblown alcohol and charred wood.  I just cant find much to like in this one.  I guess its just not for me.

Bottle. A bit of head on dark mahogany. Smells like strong liquor. Cleans the sinuses for a week. Drinking this makes me feel like I am 13 and stealing "samples" from someones liquor cabinet. Huge alcohol wamth and burn. Underneath is a nice maple molasses flavour that I would like to have sans alcohol burn.

DØE Festival, Valby, DK.
Tap, 270511.
Black with small head. Aroma of roasted malt and alcohol. Flavor unbalanced the same.

Tasted at CAGarvies House, thank you!
Brandy and vanilla on the nose with a smoky flavour and alcohol burn on nose a throat. Cheesy finish.

Bottled 4 cl (Beer Hunters)
Deep amber-ruby color, no head. Aroma of Madeira wine, alcohol, raisins ... Full-bodied. High viscocity. Burning alcohol, salt, licorice, some notes of Madeira (raisins, plums). Out of 3 (TNP, STB, EOH) I like this most.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2011 Bottle; pour is dark amber with a beige head that doesnt retain well. The nose is Insane. Keep your nose on this one for 2 seconds and you might as well put your nose on a tiki torch filled with fuel. Which we did. The tiki torch was easier to deal with. The flavor profile is like gasoline; caramel, toffee, booze, gasoline, chocolate, booze; What an utterly ridiculous brew ; Of which I drank a ton of and lived.

Snifter at BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh. Pours a deep, oily black which sits impressively and dauntingly in the glass. Wonderful aroma - sherry, alcohol, smoke, chocolate with a little bit of motor oil as well. Tastes lovely as well - a touch confused at the start before a wonderful multi-phase ending. Some syrupy sweetness, dark fruit, sherry and a touch of burnt rubber to start with, before folding into more defined fruity spiciness, and then a smokey finish. Nice liqueur mouthfeel too. If I may be permitted a bad metaphor, with the smoke and burnt rubber notes, with the oily appearance and mouthfeel, this beer is essentially Jim Clarks 1967 Lotus in a drink. Not just because of the vintage motorsport taste of it, but also because its potent, wild, dangerous and exciting. End of metaphor.

Small sample provided at R.F.D. in DC. Poured a dark, ruby red color, no head. I had high hopes after having Sink the Bismarck, and well - this didnt deliver at all. What Sink the Bismarck did well, this did not. The brew was almost cloyingly sweet - way too hot. As Ralph Wiggum on The Simpsons would say, "They taste like burning."

#3000! Bottle with big thanks to adnielsen. This cork was hard as hell to get out. Took 2 guys to do it. This pours a very dark brown color with some orange notes. Light to no carbonation. Aroma is maple syrup, black licorice, molasses and stout stout alcohol. This is warm and strings the nostrils. Flavor is super warm, lots of maple notes and warm tingles. This tingles all the way down. Lots of tingly booze over the palate. Finishes like a burning mint on the back of the throat. I am also pulling some rich coffee notes. Wow. Crazy........but I dont know if I like it. Has some similarities to the Triple Bock but burns.

Bottle at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2011 
AR: vinos, maderia, plums
AP: reddish, there are bits and pices floating around in the wee sample - yummy!
F: sprity, maderia, sprity (I had to pour out most of the sample - to strong)

Bottle shared by my brother WesIRS.  Dark brown pour with thick legs like a wine being poured into a glass. No head or even carbonation.  This is one hell of a beer?  This beast is very complex with aromas of sherry, chocolate, scotch whiskey, and lots of smoke. This doesnt really taste much like a beer. It really burns going down like a scotch. Has lots of liquid smoke and beef jerky taste. Not great but definitely glad I got to try this expensive, once highest ABV brew!

Has no carbonation or head to speak of. Very viscous brew with brown to orange colour.Aromas are boozy like port but has a some what slight malt note as well. It is a spicy brew! it burns and kicks the throat on the way down. There is some fruity notes in the mid palate but that quickly disappears before the booze burn kicks back in. Has an almost charcoal quality as well.

Pours dark brown. No head smells like brandy, almost has a aroma. Tastes nice, but it. Burns me. Tastes very nice but at this point it is more a spirit in my opinion. Too strong for beer. Fruity. Woody, boozey.

Bottle, with massive thanks to hobbersr. Pours clear chocolate brown, almost no head, no lacing. Nose is really boozy, like Kahlua and brandy, with a hint of tequila. Wow is this boozy, with notes of light fruit esters, some cocoa, a bit of Tootsie Roll, but wow is the alcohol dominating. Glad I had it, even more glad that someone else paid.

330ml bottle split 6 ways. Burnt mahogany pour with absolutely no head. The nose is offensively strong booze. A real portish feel with some maltiness and a tree-like quality. Gah!!! would be the first thing that comes to mind on the palate. This shit is fucking hot with a burning roasted malt and fire feel. Finishes like a strong cough drop and last for 6 1/2 weeks. Interesting to be sure but FAR from drinkable.

This was a tremendously interesting and powerful beer, no doubt about that. Too much for me to have more than a few ounces of it. Massive sweetness, alcohol, but you can also picked up the very whiskey feels. Glad I tried it once, but I wouldnt be in a hurry to go at it again.

Svårt att recensera som en öl. Mörkbrun öl utan något skum. Doftar sött, ungefär som en lagrad rom, men med inslag av något eget jag inte riktigt kan identifiera. Även smaken påminner om någon destilerad, lagrad sprit men med en egen karaktär. Drack 2,5 cl av denna från en nyöppnad flaska på Brewdog Bar i Glasgow.

November 13, 2010 - Waterloo tasting with blankboy, jerc, mabel and tupalev. 330ml bottle courtesy of j&m.  Almost black with a minimal frothy beige head - but it looks thick and mysterious so Im-a giveit a fo-ah.  Heavenly aroma - Islay whiskey with some lactose and very light grain - iodine, hemp, salt ... and, oh yes, alcohol (peat of course, but with an Islay thats implied).  Taste - boooooozy;  and peat;  thats it - as Jeff says, peat juice and vodka - "liquid smoke with ash and alcohol added."  Slick, boozy, long smoky/peaty finish - I loved it, but may never try it again - if I want whiskey, I will friggin DRINK whiskey.

AROMA: nose: fenols, wood, almost old-port like quality; mouth: coffee-flavoured chocolate, hints of fudge, old port wine, grassy.
APPEARANCE: dark black, no foam
TASTE: medium sweetness
PALATE: oily feel, flat, long finish
OVERALL: a very complex beer that is in its special league of distillery-strength beers. The port-wine almost velvety smoothness combined with coffee-flavour chocolate really works here.

Thanks to Jaksmart for sharing his birthday present ;-) Ruby red of colour without any head. An aroma of vegetables, hops, caramel, liqurice and tar. A flavor of hops, malt, tar, dry, liqurice and some alcohol.

I could smell this from the other room.  Huge rum and sherry aroma, big on the booze.  Not sure if this needs more less time but the oxidation character/malt character wasnt completely together, this might be a result of the freezing I suppose, nice licorice, raisin, whisky, sherry and rum flavors.  Ugly murky brown.  Need to sit down with this one a bit to get the full picture Im sure, but I prefer the bismark for sure at this point.

Bottle shared at StateLine by Bruce... Damn this is terrible. Cognac aroma. Harsh alcohol. Dark brown/black in color. Very viscous. Taste is alcohol and more alcohol. ugh.... tough to swallow.  Glad I tried this but this beer is just a novelty.
3/5 i mörkhet. Luktar superlim. Lite tjock och väldigt spritig i smaken. Spritig och lätt träig eftersmak.

330 ml bottle, Batch 008, best before 27-07-20.  After taking it out of the fridge, I let the bottle sit out for around 30-35 minutes before opening it.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown/black, and what little head it had fizzled away pretty quickly.  No lacing at all, but there are "legs" that I can see when I swirl the beer around the glass.  I dont think Ive noticed that in a beer before, I only usually see that when Im drinking liquor.  Aroma is very boozy.  Along with the booze, I can also smell dark fruit, smoke/peat, chocolate, and some molasses.  The brew tastes like booze (sherry), smoke/peat, dark fruit (raisins, cherries, figs) and molasses.  Its still hot, but the other flavors arent overpowered by the hotness.  Theres also a boozy smoky/sweet finish that lingers around for a long time.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a syrupy and very, very slick and coating with low carbonation.  As Ive noticed with other BrewDog stouts Ive tried in the past, this is a thinner stout than Im used to but since I liked the syrupy slickness Im not going to knock down the score too much.  I think this is a solid beer, itll be interesting to see how this one ages.  Definitely worth a try, its surprisingly drinkable for a 32% ABV brew even though it took me about an hour to finish the bottle.

Thanks to Veldrid, LeopoldStoch and Megatron for sharing this huge beer. Pours dark brown or black with no head. As I swirl it I my glass it hangs on the edges for while before collects back to the bottom. From the second this bad boy was poured the booze was all I could smell. After a few sniffs I picked up on peat, smoke and some coffee. Taste was of booze (hot), licorice, chocolate, coffee, tabacco and a touch of vanilla. Mouthfeel was thick and hot. Finish was long smokey roasted malt and alcohol.
Sampler at CBF 2011-05-27. Clear mahogany with no head. Boozy, fusel, caramel on the nose. Prunes, alcohol, fusel, bitter and an earthy finish. Alcoholic warmth. Full body. Oily texture.

Pours pitch black with no head. Aroma is extremely strong alcohol, roasted malts and dark fruits. Flavor strikes very hard at first but then immediately becomes surprisingly pleasant. The roasted malts come through strongly especially in the finish. I really didnt expect to enjoy this as much as I did.

Thanks to Jeff, Chris, and Brandon for this very generous offering!  Pours a muddy black with a thin veil of light getting through the edges of the beer.  The aroma is actually very nice with notes of chocolate, caramel, definitely alcohol, vanilla, and some very nice scotch notes of peat, smoke, earth, dirt.  This is flat on the palate and shows its heat as soon as it touches the lips.  The heat really builds quickly with this.  The hottest beer Ive had yet.  There are flavors of smoke and peat with caramel, even some vanilla and a small hint of chocolate as well.  Very much like whiskey with the wood coming through along with the beery aspects.  The finish is rather hot but sweet.  Im surprised to have enjoyed this as much as I did.
Clear dark amber without head. Aroma is very sweet and lots of whisky. Extremely sweet and rather bitter. Dry finish with burning alcohol. Unpleasant. 260511

From bottle at The Bishops Arms, Södermalm. Dark brown with no head. Alcoholic and smoked malts nose. Hardcore smoked malts, warming alcohol, meaty and peaty. Full-bodied. Super-special-extra points for originality. Complex whisky notes an added bonus.

2 oz. sample from bottle. Rating #2200! $20 @ Palmer Place. They charged this much for a taste of Utopias, so its a value. Big sweet smell of sherry and brandy. No foam, just a dark ruby beer that bounces off a lot of room lights. Smell now has notes of Baileys Irish Cream. First tiny sip is a bottomless pit of brown malt. Full of alcohol fumes, but somehow not hot. Just the first two sips have left the inside of my mouth with a coating of malt and resin. Heck, its varnish and a clear coat on top, too. Even less than an ounce worth is quite intoxicating. No one who doesnt know the story of this drink would think its a beer. Yet its nothing less than, say, a Krampus distilled and reduced to its barest essence. No carbonation on my tongue. Definitely more potent than an 80 proof brandy. Alcoholic to the end.

2 cl sample @ OHaras, Tampere.
Pours a dark brown colour without a head. Aroma of strong glue and alcohol. Flavour of glue, peated malts, whisky and citrus. Medium bodied with a burning alcohol finish. Quite unpleasant really. Nothing compared to Sink the Bismarck.

Beautiful ruby color, no head. Aroma has surprisingly little alcohol, raisins, bouillon, oak, some hops as well as plenty of oaky and bourbon-ish stuff. Taste is - obviously - very strong with cocoa, bourbon, peat, roast, smoke, sausage, some dry hops in the finish. Very interesting.
Bottle. Dark brown with no head. Flavour is roasted malts, alcohol, burning and dark fruit.

Flaske: Først og fremmest props for at presse citronen. Når det er sagt var det umuligt at drikke selve øllen. Langt mere alkohol end øl. Udseendet er flot og ligner en stout. God duft, men smagen er ren alkohol. Ikke min stil.
Bottle at Klooster, interesting to try but really doesnt taste that great. Strong alchohol. I find it quite bad.
Being a scotch drinker I really appreciated this. It didnt just taste like beer extract, but like a complex scotch with smokey and hop flavors mixed in. Great job.

Crushed at OB Liquids & Solids.  Thought this was a barley wine?  2 oz pour.  Heavy on the alcohol of course, but its more well-hidden than youd think.  Pretty sweet, dark fruity flavor with a cool smokiness.  Impressive there are so many flavors despite the alcohol burn.

Bottle. Has been open for about a week, but kept tightly sealed. Pours a dark, reddish brown. No head. Thick, sweet, slightly tart aroma; dark fruits, roasted malt, bread, hint of vanilla. Flavour is tart with sweet liquorice and smoke in front; sweet, dark fruits in the back. As it develops, the smoke dwindles and gives more room to the dark fruits and, to a lesser extent, the liquorice, as well as peat (guess thats where the smoke went). Finish is more sweet liquorice and dark fruits, with smoked notes resembling whisky (more peat, I guess), lingering. Also a lingering sweet alcoholic note, reminding me of first of Cinzano Rosso, and later of cognac. Overall interesting and actually rather good; good aroma and flavour and the alcohol is well-balanced and doesnt nearly resemble the high %. Still, its not knocking my socks off. 18.05.11.

The alcohol in this is well hidden.............right. Pours a pretty clear dark reddish color with no head whatsoever. The aroma consists of peat, smoked meat, chocolate, figs, and of course, alcohol. Strong alcoholic whiskey and smoke flavor with undercurrents of cocoa, spice and fruit. The flavor seemed to be quite complex, but was a bit overpowered by the alcohol. Not sure Id label this one as an imperial stout. Its quite thin; more the consistency of whiskey than beer. Definitely intense, its not something Id probably spend the money on again, but i had to be tried.

Bottle shared by Jaksmart, thanks Jakob. Pours deep ruby with no head at all. The color is very nice. Aroma has no alcohol at all - very impressive - but contains coffee, chocolate, oak, peat, bourbon notes, nice vanilla sweetness. Taste has lots of alcohol burn, oak, vanilla, peat, whisky notes, strong chocolate, berries nice sweetness, very dry finish. The alcohol is extremely well hidden in the aroma. I wasnt expecting much from this one, but it surprised me by actually being good.

Pours dark ruby red with no head. Aroma is chocolate, bourbon, oak, ripe fruits, peat and surprisingly enough, not too much alcohol for 32% !. Taste is INTENSE with huge roast, peat, smoke, oaky wood, strong intense cocoa, alcohol/whiskey and extremely dry. longest duration ever.. Thank you Jaksmart for sharing this crazy little penguin!

Split a bottle 8 ways at the Mexican Food Factory.
Aroma of smoked meats (capicola?) and dark figs and raisins.  Appears thick and viscus with no head.  Tasted of peat, scotch and dark fruits.  Overall, not as crazy as I thought it was going to be but still pretty intense.  It felt like a privilege.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2011 Bottle sampled at Bishops Folkungagatan.
Clear dark brown/black. No head. No lacings.
Aroma is boozy and burnt with lots of licorice, herbs, burnt butterscotch and some wood.
Strong boozy flavour.  Burnt butterscotch, lots of tar and licorice, herbs.
No carbonation. Boozy burning body. Fun but not that fun.
Sampled it again at SB&WF 2011 and its waaaay too boozy to be enjoyable. Could work at the dentist though.

I hear, "its got smoke" coming from those around me who managed to sip this treat first.  You can smell this beer from a mile away.  Dark brown in color, but transparent when looking through it from above.  A serious beer... heck, its beyond that.  Its pungent aroma reminds me of a strong steak sauce or marinade.  Very strong, like rubbing alcohol mixed with a  heavy steak sauce.  The smell alone almost knocks you out.  The flavor reminds me of serious BBQ.  Its really hard to drink a mouthful of this divine beer... really, a beverage best enjoyed by the sip.  Strong, thin, yet beefy.  Wow.  Wow.  Wow.  Wow.  New words will have to be coined to properly describe this beer.  An incredibly well-done concoction.  Worth the buy if you can pace yourself to finish it over a few weeks, or shared with friends with good taste...
Bottle at Klooster, interesting to try but really doesnt taste that great.  Strong alchohol burn of course and little resemblance of an imperial stout.

Bottle courtesy of darkguardian.  Clear mahogany pour with no head.  Pungent brandy nose.  I mean it actually stings the old nostrils.  Insane alcohol taste with cherry and smoke flavors lurking in the background.

Bottle into a shot glass...Light brown, that is very watery looking, no carbonation at all, not much to look at...Incredibly strong aroma of fusel alcohol, roasty, very hot stinging my nostril, a tinge of peppers, interesting but not very good...The taste is horrendous! Its so hot, burns. Burnt alcohol and charred wood Is all I get this. There were 3 of us and we couldnt finish a 2oz pour.

I was so fascinated to try this and this is beyond terrible. I total liquor but not a good one. SKIP this.

Dark opaque in colour with not much head - syrupy round the glass like a Pedro Ximinez sherry. The nose is alcoholic, maybe tarry but definitely of balsam wood. The taste is very much the same but the flavours are overpowered by the alcohol burn. Great experience but more interesting than good.

Small glass at Beer Temple. Pitch black with no head. Nose is like licorice and port and whisky. Texture very syrupy of molasses. Nice oak taste and bite, with whisky notes. Quite dark and strong but waayyyyyyyy too strong for me so I just had a bit, and happy I did not buy a full bottle.

Deep amber in color with no head, a few slight bubbles around the edges.  Boozey, rubbing-alcohol-like aroma with malty-syrupy barleywine-esque notes.  The taste is syrupy-malty at first but quickly becomes liquor-like; its smokey (not quite burnt), with a smoothenes (like a tequilla shot) and a strong warming sensation that coats the mouth and throat.  Best way to describe it is like malty liquor...feels like alcohol fumes in your mouth, but it is much more drinkable (and sip-able) than a typical liquor.

Notes: Pour from a bottle at The Beer Temple, Amsterdam

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2011 21 March 2011 bottle. 
whisky appearance in glass, thin w/ legs but dark brown. great nose. pink nail polish remover and maple syrup w/ some wood (fresh pine?) and white grape juice. really thin body, dry. not great. taste is white grape and old oak. something is burnt. i like the taste but i have a hard time judging it as a beer. 

Original rating/tasting (7/10 4/5 7/10 4/5 15/20 = 3.7)
almost black and looks totally flat. it actually has legs like whisky
couldnt place the smell for a while, then i realized it smells just like port. more like a dry oaky port than a sweet tawny port
beer is really thick and syrupy!
very oaky w/ a bite that has to be the alcohol. this is hard to drink. beer is drunk in swallows but this cant be drunk that way. it is interesting but not something id drink again due primarily to the £35 price tag
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2011 Bottle from Brewdog Online Shop. Really strong phenolic tar aroma. Very dark brown colour, no head. Very strong treacle tar alcohol taste. Great idea, tastes horrible.

Sample, draught, at Saint-Bocks 4th anniversary, savoured on October 16 2010; eye: cognac, clear, no effervescence, no head; nose: alcohol, sugar, malt, light pepper; mouth: alcohol, sugar, malt, pepper, finale in alcohol, full body, alcoholic texture; overall: disappointing

FRANÇAIS 

Échantillon, en fût, bue au Saint-Bock, soirée 4ième anniversaire, savourée le 16 octobre 2010; il : cognac, claire, pas deffervescence, pas de mousse; nez : alcool, sucre, malt, léger poivre; bouche : alcool, sucre, malt, poivre, finale en alcool, corsée, texture alcoolique; en résumé : décevante

Aroma:Smokey, malty, dark malts, hot alcohol. It smells a little like a whiskey.

Appearance:Dark, cola colored. Its pretty flat. It doesnt have lacing so much as a syrupy residue that sticks to the side of the glass.

Taste:The foretaste is smokey and tangy. Theres a huge malty sweetness that peaks in the midtaste. Theres smoke, woody flavors, and hops in the aftertaste.

Palate:There is hot alcohol in the foretaste and aftertaste, but it takes a break in the midtaste. Theres actually not as much hot alcohol as I thought there would be. Its very thick and syrupy. No carbonation to speak of.

Overall:This beer is quite tasty, and a much better beer than I thought it would be. Theres a ton of complex whiskey related flavors (smoke and wood) that give the beer a lot of depth.

Pours dark brown, almost black in color.  Aroma is full of malts, a little smoke, and soy sauce.  Flavor is full of malts, soy sauce, barley, smoke, and booze.  Leaves a harsh malt and smoke finish.  This is by far the maltiest beer Ive ever had.  But for 32% what else can you expect.  Thanks to my fiance for the Christmas present.

Bottle poured into a shot glass at tasting. Very dark brown with basically no head. Smell of brandy, plum, banana, thick and complex. Taste of alcohol, oak and some fruit, golden syrup, molasses. Big malty, salty alcohol with some burn, but not overpowering.

Bottle courtesy of rciesla.  Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  Smells of dark fruit, figs, licorice, tobacco.  Tastes of raisins, prunes, cognac, toffee, some big roasty hints, peppery.  Alcohol is there but masked.  Great beer!

1.5oz snifter 
32.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on January 17, 2011 at "The Beerbistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer was a very dark brown with no head.  The aroma was alcohol, roasted malt, and wood.  The mouthfeel was full bodied with no carbonation.  The flavour was dry, smoke, malty, with a hint of licorice.

Bottle shared at home. Pours black with dark red tones. Very little head. Loads of roasted malts and a prominent flavor of oak. Some smoke. This beer is meant to be shared. An interesting brew. Not your everyday stout.

Rating #200 for this beer and rating #1983 for me, significant because I have reached my birth year in ratings. 375 ml bottle from michael-pollack- thanks again, Pollack! The bottle indicated a best by date of 10/28/2020, so Im guessing it was bottled 10/28/2010 (batch 7). I opened this one and shared it at The Royale last night, as some of the local guys heard I had one and wanted to all try it. Pours a dark, cloudy brown color with almost no head, just a little ring. Aroma of tobacco, smoked and roasted malts, charred wood, and a whole lot of alcohol. In fact, keeping this up to your nose for more than a few seconds is like taking a big whiff of mineral spirits in terms of the heat you feel. But despite the smoke and heat, I liked the smell. Flavor of alcohol throughout, along with cigar tobacco, roasted malts, charred wood, and some malty, sugary sweetness. Medium-full bodied, with mild carbonation and a very boozy, very ashy mouthfeel. Bitterness from the alcohol is present throughout. The 32% is in no way masked here. This is one insane beer and Im glad I was able to try this and share it.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2011 Bottle. Yep, here it is, the pretty dark hawk... It pours out in a clear reep reddish amber colour with a small bubbly off-white head. Big aroma of wood, booze, sweet licorice, whiskey,port, nuts and tar. Full-bodied with big hot and belly-warming flavours of salty licorice, wood, alcohol, tar, black chocolate, black pepper and used cigarettes. Long warming and as well quite boozy finish of salty licorice, prunes, pepper, alcohol and brown sugar.Crazy stuff of course but I still considering this as a beer after all.

4 cl glass. The Gallows Bird XIV Real Ale Festival, Espoo, Finland.
Dark reddish brown colour with no head.
Strong aroma of portwine, malt and alcohol. 
Flavour is strongly vinous with portwine, brandy and very strong maltiness. Some alcohol in taste but not in a bad way. Disappears quickly (both glass/mouth). Warms like hell. Short aftertaste. Extreme but not too hard to handle.
Bottle: Dark, extreem dark. Nose a bit smokey, taste licorice but also salpether. To overpowering. Yet a brilliant "brew".

Sample from urbancaver (ba).  Pours a slightly hazy dark amber color with no head to speak of at all.  The aroma was caramel sweetness, huge scotch alcohol,  and peaty smokiness.  The flavor was quite hot.  Sweet caramel malts, smoky peat, woody with abundant alcohol.  In a strange way I find this better than most of the Paradox series mainly because there is some idea of the base beer.  I am happy to have had the opportunity to try this.

Sampled out of a hand bottled sample.  I cant imagine drinking a 12 oz. bottle of this.  Deep caramel color.  Alcohol nose, burnt caramel corn and deep dark fruit aroma.  Rich buttery flavor.  Rum cake, raisen bread, rich ripe fruit.  Hop resin and alcohol flavors.  This is not abusively alcoholic, but is definitely strong.  Really nice complex beer.

Bottle [375ml] shared with HogTownHarry, tupalev, jerc & mabel -- c/o j&m. Pours black with no head. Aroma: Man oh man, this is all alcohol with a ton of smoke, peat and ash -- so much alcohol! Flavour: Fuckity fuck this is boozy and theres so much ash and smoke -- it burns! Long, dry, smoky finish. Full bodied. Definitely interesting and unique and Im glad I got to try it.

375ml Bottle:  Aroma of peat, smoked cheese, smoked meat, smoke, ash, and whiskey.  Poured very dark brown/very deep amber/mahogany in color with a tiny, tan/brown head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout as a film on top of the beer.  Hazy.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet, lightly bitter, and lightly spicy.  Tastes of peat, light marzipan, roasted malt, oak, smoke, whiskey, slight tar, and slight tobacco.  Medium to full body.  Sightly chalky then slightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Peat, oak, whiskey, malt, slight coconut, slight marzipan, light tar, and smoke finish is dry.

Sampled from the bottle. Poured a clear bronze with no head whatsoever. Aroma was extremely boozy with an underlying peat notes as well as some dark grains. Flavor was extremely boozy as well, but dark fruit, peat and roasted malts come through underlying.

An intense aroma, toasted bread, toffee like. Dark brown color, no carbonation at all, dark brown head. Heavy body resembling a spirit and not a beer.  Very alcohol like, thick and bitter finishing. Somewhat difficult to judge as a beer!

One of the most gorgeous beer pours Ive ever seen.  Deep clear mahogany with just the bare tiniest bit of carbonation.  Aroma is peat, smoke, malt, alcohol, sea salt, iodine, a lot of character in just the nose.  The Scotch is apparent.  Flavor is alcohol, but smooth.  More smoke and peat, but not overwhelmingly so.  Stout malt character carries it through.  A little smokey for my taste, but not so much that it wasnt immensely enjoyable.

Bottle. pours pitch black with no head. STRONG aroma of peat/smoke and whisky. Intense flavor of whisky, smoky peat, roasted malts and subtle caramel with a warming roasty smoky dry finish. Bottle from state line

Thanks again to a great coworker for sharing this and Bismarck!  Black color with a very small head.  Monster rum, molases and raisin aroma.  Quite boozy smelling.  Very similar flavor.  Added some more dark fruits, maybe prune.  Light barrel char.  Quite sweet.  Seems like a hot port.  Oddly enough, I think I like the Bismarck a bit better and as insane as this sounds, that one might have been more "balanced".  Still, enjoyable and glad I got to try it.

Sampled sipped thanks to Mike at OTM. I usually wouldnt rate such a small sample but at 32% and about $100 Im gonna call it good enough since I feel I got a failry good evaluation of the brew. The appearance is a carmel/chocolate flowing brown color. Almost a tawny hue I guess. The aromas are mostly alcohol with a lot of whiskey profile. The entry is heavy roasted malts and whiskey a very nice start. The middle quickly turns into a soy sauce which slowly leads to a solid dark fruit prune juice notes. The finish starts smoky but it mellows into a whiskey barrel graininess that just keeps going. Like liking the inside of a spent barrel. The mouth is very full bodied hot but not as much as I expected (at least with the small sample). Overall better then I was expecting. I could see this potentially aging into something pretty nice. Although Ill have to say it is no where worth the price tag for a full bottle. Hopefully I can taste again and add some more note. Thanks Mike!

Ok. So. Yep. I had this one of kind brew at a Lieverkusen Beerfest in Germany back in August I guess. So I forgot all about it until, I realized looking at a bottle of brewdog, this is my first taste of their beer. So lets see if my memory serves me correctly...ah yes.  I asked for a bottle and they said, um well we serve it in these 10cl glasses here. I said oh ok, 4 euro for 10cl, what a bargain, and they reminded me it was 32% and I said ok start off small. So, they pored it, it was a dark, rick mahogany brown color. Syrupy, dark, caramely, barley wine looking guy. I smelled it, it instantly hit my nose as alcohol, fresh bread, cereal, smoke and tobacco.  The taste was of beer first, with a brandy/congac taste immediatley after, with hints of smoke/oak/roasted malt/honey/dark beer and leather. It was complex but again I had 2 sips. It lingered on the palate for a minute and subdued, but you got the vanilla, oak, smokes brew sensation and almost wine and brandy leftover. a hell of a beer. It was strong but not unpleasant. Its not a simple mystery to its ingredients because all of us agreed on a few items then we just lost our focus and kept drinking more. So overall a definite must try, because to call it beer insults it I think, you must look deeper and you will

Sampled at "the strongest beer in the world" tasting session on Ørsted Ølbar. The best experience among the 6 samples. Dark brown/black with no head. Aroma of dark mellow chocolate, caramel sharp alchohol and smoke, nice. Very complex flavor. Chocolate and alchohol with a dry ashy smoked finish. Suprisingly plesant and interesting beer.

Bottle from La Bodega.  Clear dark brown with no head.  Big smokey alcoholic aroma with scotch notes and hints of dark fruit lingering on the nose.  Tastes of leather, smoke, scotch, tobacco,wood, light bitter chocolate and caramel notes with a big alcoholic bite and lingering smoke and leather in the finish.  Thick syrupy palate.  Points for being BIG and interestingly complex.  While it hits a bit pungently up front, nice flavors reveal themselves with additional sips.

[330ml bottle, gift from Jim - huge thanks due!!!] Deep yet vivid ruby-black, no head or fizz.  Vicious alcohol burn at first, put soon pungent flavoursstart to spiral out, different and surprising with each sip; roasted malt, port, deep earthy woodland mulch, plain chocolate, salty marmite, peat and cherryade, with smoke in the finish.  Sweet with bitter hints from the roasted malt, and with a drying finish that avoids any suggestion of stickiness.  Scary and bizarre, but excellent nevertheless and a lot of fun (providing you share it!).
bottle from my uncle. Paet and somke to excess! strong phenolic nose and a good punch of smpke pickled alcohol.oily consistency and pure madness.

Sampled at SBWF-10
Pitch black. No head.
Leather and sweet fruits. Pretty sweet and too alcoholic.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2011 head: none , even when poured in very very high 
colour: dark coffee brown 
smell: alcohol, coffee licqour, rich dark chocolat, very very strong, stingy in the nose , bit of vanilla and oak, sweet/candy , very nice ! 
taste: very salty malty start, coffee , burned malts , malts and malts !!, very stingy alcohol, candy , bit of anis and lots of herbs/spices , aftertaste is oak , bitter and dry , overall palate is bitter and alcoholisch , very grassy aftertaste , taste is good only the alcohol overwhelms it a bit too much , wouldve been better if it had just the warming stomach feel like the struise 26% beers have .... so the 8 is mostly based on the start and the aftertaste of the beer excluding the alcohol taste ... and even tough you sip this bottle for 4 hours like i did , expect to be drunk !!

Pour is totally carbonation free.  Dark color with hints of red.  Nose is just divine, smoky, earthy, and sweet.  Taste is a bunch of smoke and peat, like a thick glass of scotch.  Alcohol doesnt come through near as much as I thought it would.  Mouthfeel is heavy.

Bottle at a tasting on 17th Dec. Holy Fuck! This shit is strong. Pours dark cola, pretty much black. No head on it at all. Aroma is a rather intense malt, with a strong hit of alcohol, and slight notes of oak. To quote Ralph Wiggum, "It tastes like burning". Quite hot from the alcohol, it does have a smoothness to it once you get past the Holy Fuck stage.

Bottle 355ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is malty with notes of caramel, alcohol and oak. Taste is very intense malty, sweet and bitter with a very long aftertaste. Texture is oily with flat carbonation.

Pours a deep black in color with an almost orange tan head.... Aroma is oak and burnt malts.... Flavor is very sweet up front, but gives way to an almost bitter and painful finish.... Syrupy consistency, reminds me of motor oil, finish kinda tastes like it too.. Not the best.

This beer pours a deep brown with no head.  The aroma is burnt coffers, roasted coffee, heavy dark chocolate, with a sting alcohol burn.  The mouthfeel is sticky, super heavy and extremely bitter with burnt coffee, and dark chocolate.  This was obviously heavy on the alcohol!  The flavors and smell were awesome hut the strong alcohol really hits the palate and nose hard.  Cheers!

Thank you Enzofan.   Mahogany pour with no head or carbonation.  Dark fruit and caramel/toffee on the nose.  Not much hop presence in aroma.  Smoke, alcohol, caramel, and oak dominate the flavor.  Reminds me of cognac.  Medium/full mouthfeel.  A bit of heat in the finish.  Very, very drinkable for 32% abv.  Enjoyable, and I would love to have another.

[3478-20101113] Bottle. Bandaid boozy wooden barrel malt aroma has a lot of smoke. Hazy, dark brown body with no head and thick legs. Hot smokey peppers and ash flavour has a long smokey aftertaste. Full body is all booze. HOLY CRAP this is spicy -- more like whiskey, not beer.
(c/o DuctTape, w/ blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc, tupalev)

Bottle: Pours an opaque black no cap. Aroma is intense peat smoke, oaky and roasty, some tobacco and licorice.

This is rich and oily to the palate...a lot like some wild herbal liquer with smokey presense.

Flavor: Peat smoke predominates...oily mouth feel....woody, some sweetness, alcohol hidden - only shows up as a salty side note, medicinal, licorice, tar...figging wild stuff.

Not an every day drink for me....too much smoke taste

chocolate, coffee, roasty, alcohol, soy sauce, licorice, black, clear, brown foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, full body, oily feel, sticky, flat, long finish, 
Wow var min första reaktion, har aldrig smakat något likanade. Mucket intressat "öl".

Pours a clear, quite dark brown with no head. Sweet with a light bitterness. Quite malty with aromas of peat and smoke. Also aromas of leather and hints of whiskey. Some residual sugars. Full bodied with a slightly sticky mouthfeel. No carbonatin. Long peaty finish.
Sample at Stockholm Beer Festival 2010. Black beer with no head. Whisky aroma, malty, oily, tar, chocolate. Strong flavor, whisky, alcohol, chocolate, tar.

I had this beer at Churchills in San Marcos during the New Brew Thursday 1st Anniversary Party.  The first flavor that hit me was salty followed shortly by overcooked bacon. This beer wasnt for me

Förvånadsvärt ljus vätska tyckte jag, stärk doft av malt och en hel del lakrits. Vätskan är mycket oljig och tjock, smaken består av lakrits och malt. Värmen är självklart ganska tydlig. Kul att ha provat, men det räckte med 5 cl.

Ive been highly anticipating this. 330mL bottle, from Firefly Fine Wines and Ales for $85, split amongst three of us. Pours dark amber with no head. Firey aroma of whiskey, sherry, molasses and lots and lots of alcohol. Very smokey flavour initially, with a blast of whiskey and burnt caramel throughout the middle. Alcohol burns on the finish, obviously, with the smokiness and burnt caramel characteristics remaining noticeable. 4 oz. is definitely more than enough. A very special treat.

3 samples at Chancey Smiths- Wow, this one takes a long while even to sip at. Very still opaque coffee black, with a thin ring of head. Intense smokey nose has peat and iodine, much like an Islay malt, and has just a hint of espresso. The smoke permeates any flavours here, and I get a bit of medicinal saltiness as well. Oily, strong and marked peaty finish. Finish is briney with heavy bitterness. An Islay lovers dream beer. Great!

Black, no head, thick lacings on the glas. Instense aroma of whiskey, smoke, oak and booze. Taste is like aroma with some dark dried fruit added. Interesting and fun to try, tastes pretty good, but not really what i call a beer

15$/1oz. Aroma of smoked malts, wood, coffee and wine. It feels like scotch/wine/imperial stout hybrid, but not as intense as I anticipated. Taste is closer to scotch or wine that beer. You really can feel the Speyside saltiness. The palate is the major flaw in this otherwise very intriguing and enjoyable beer. The mouthfeel is thin and quite sticky, far from the richness of a worldclass spirit. Gets few points for originality but still a too expensive and cool tick.

Bottle from Rotary Pub, Göteborg. Shared between 7 of us, which was more than enough. On October 9, 2010.Clear dark brownish red color, no head. Salty, vinous scent. Sweet, intensly bitter, very very salty taste. Long alcohol and salty aftertaste. Warming to burning alcohol.. Smooth mouthfeel, high bitterness. Char coal, tar, smoke, salt, and really not good at all.If sold similar to Underberg bottles perhaps would be perceived better?

Sampled at Brewdog dinner at beerbistro. In terms of the brewdog crazy strong beers, I liked this one better than the Bismarck. Dark reddish-brown colour with zero head. Aroma is alcohol, coffee, and strong whisky notes. Flavour is smoked malt, coffee, heather, whiskey, alcohol. Alcoholic finish. Intense imperial stout. Like the Bismarck, to be drank like a scotch instead of a beer, but intriguing.

Bottle (33 cl) shared with some dudes at Rotary Pub, Göteborg, Sweden. Dark reddish brown, no head. Strong harsh charcoal and smoke aroma, with heavy alcoholic notes. Extreme unpleasant bitterness. Hugely undrinkable.
Thanks to my buddy Matt for bringing this over.  Pours viscous black with no head or carbonation.  Nose of smoked meats and scotch.  A great sub for scotch and a cigar!

Bottle at the Ginger Man, NYC. Pours reddish-brown with a slight, tan head. Strong roasted malt aroma with smoke, peat and booze. Flavor is intense and fairly sweet, with more dark malts, some caramel. Full bodied with almost no carbonation. Finishes with some boozy burn and lingering smoke and peat notes. Pretty good.

bottle at Patricks. Dark amber colour with no head. Aroma is alcohol, coffee, heather, whiskey. Flavour is smoked malt, coffee, heather, whiskey, alcohol. Alcoholish finish. Intense imperial stout. Nearly too much in my opinion.

Sampled this nuclear drink at the Brewdog meeting at Craftheads back in feb. 2010. Truly a mindblowing brew. Difficult to classify as "beer" but works well as a bridge between whiskey and beer. Very very strong alcohol flavors...but fun to share and sip!

Darkbrown color, no head. Whisky, smoke, tar, vanilla in the aroma. Also some chocolate and toffee. Flavour is whisky, chocolate, toffee and vanilla. Medium to fullbodied, very soft carbonation. Fun to try!
Nose is like a beef jerky liqueur, taste is hot, hurts the lungs, very smoky, complex, should suck but is actually very damn good.

(Bottle, batch 5, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a brown body with crazy legs.  Aroma of butter, caramel, wood, diesel fuel, smoke, tar, and butterscotch.  Flavor of wood, alcohol, ash, and roasted malt with a dry finish.

Bottle. Pours a clear brownish/black color with a small fast disappearing off-white head. Has a smoky roasted caramel aroma with alcoholic hints. Roasted malty licorice and caramel flavor with smoky hints and some hints of alcohol. Has a warming roasted malty smoky licorice finish.
Sample at Øl og Mat 2010, Oslo. Rich herbal and malty nose. Alcoholic, herbal taste. I dont really associate this with beer, its more like Fernet Branca with a dash of malt. Intriguing though.

Amber golden colour, coppery hue. Still. An enormous nose; polished boards, raisin, spice, cream, cocoa. Epic. Enticing. The spicy, hot palate delivers warm dried fruit flavours. Very hot, prickly and raisiny. Lengthy, hot raisiny, spicy mulled wine aftertaste. Fails to match the nose. I dont know what to make of it. If indeed it is a beer, then it certainly raises the bar, in terms of interest. However, if distillation makes it something else, its at best an average, interesting spirit.

Bottle. Brown-red-black with almost no head. A smoky deeply sweet nose, with traces of caramel, alcohol and wood. 32%? I cant believe it; extremely well hidden strength. Leaves small legs on the glass, very smooth. Sweet, making me think of Tokay again (as did Tokyo*). Chocolate and some ripe fruit. Much better than I thought it would be. An Internet classic: I wish I could afford having a few bottles at home because its a damn good sipper to share with select friends!

[330ml bottle, Cornelius Beer & Wine, Edinburgh] Really impressive stuff, it pours utterly tar black and sits there menacingly. Has a massive peaty smokiness about it, both in the aroma and taste  reminiscent of Islay single malt. Clearly meant to be sipped, drunk as a de-facto spirit (which it may actually be depending on your definition of brewing), its got a very whisky-like warming burn as it goes down. In context (with a Burns supper?) it would be very good indeed, or drunk by a roaring fire with snow on the ground. I would definitely drink this compared to most spirits, just a pity the price is quite prohibitive. As my friend said I can imagine Russians drinking this [01/01/2010]
12 oz.  Poured a dark brown, very little bubbles.  This was  very interesting,  I got a ton of smoke flavor.  It smelled like a camp fire.  At 31 percent it burned and it is a definite sipper.

pure concentrated evil.. . pours a dark black, very low head, no lacing, just crazy brown legs .. . very ruff, flavors of booze, rum, tar, evil, black hole, tar and burnt match tips .. . needs about a year, to a decade .. . when i tried it with my beer tasting group it was hot but enjoyable, when i tried it at its release- amazing.. but when i sat down with a bottle myself over the course of 2 nights, the roughness came out, is fun though, it really helped my bad back .. . refudiate the haters!!

Aroma: Peat and burnt malt, no stout qualities at all
Appearance: Ruddy brown, fairly clear, touch of carbonation.
Taste: Peat and burnt malt flavored vodka, in a bad way. Ugh.
Palate: Huge alcohol burn, in a very bad way. Ugh
Overall: Im insulted people call this beer. Beer is enjoyable, this is not.

CBF 2010: Black, almost no head. Lots of aroma, smoke, whisky, pepper, sharp spice, old tree, not especially pleasent though. Flavor is heavy sweet, moderate bitter, long duration. Full body, oily texture. Flat carbonation.

Bottle - sample courtesy of GandGKevin! Pours a dark brown with ruby edges. No head at all. Pretty, sticky and thick legs on the glass. Aroma is almost pure Islay single malt. Lots of iodine, wood, peat and roasted notes. Taste is not really a beer but more a liquor. Warming alcohol up front followed by more of the Islay flavors(peat, iodine) with roasted malt, sweet malt and vanilla. Body is thick and very warming but cools as it goes down. No carbonation whatsoever. Ends with more iodine, peat, roasted malt, vanilla and sweet malt. Big thanks to Kevin for the sample!

Finally managed to get my hands on one of these, and last night me and a friend shared a bottle - a straight necessity not only due to the high ABV, but also due to the crazy price of this thing - 655 NOK (about 105 USD, current rates). I suspect Vinmonopolet have a strong saying in this, as BrewDog sells them off their website for 57 USD... :-(  Anyway, at such a price we made sure the event was enjoyable, unwrapping the penguin-decorated brown paper bag and having a laugh at the usual sharp BrewDog wit on the label. Tactical Nuclear Penguin poured out like some dark scotch; no head, deep coppery red-amber body - surprisingly transparent and liquor-like. We took quite some time with our noses down our snifters; the smell is intense and pleasant: booze (but not overpowering), wood, caramel and hints of peat and smoke. Very smooth aromatic profile. Then, it was time to raise our glasses and give the antarctic bird its proper salute. First sip hits me like a brandy or whiskey; lots of warming alcohol spreading out in a fan of flavor: whiskey, oak, smoke, tar, leather, licorice. Layer after layer. Cough syrup, caramel, chocolate, coffee. Hints of cherry somewhere in there? To uncover all the nuances took me almost as long as the drink itself, and I kept backtracking my taste buds to give room for new interpretations along the way. This is good stuff, very complex and enticing. I found myself reaching for my glass way more frequent than initially expected. Although this is a beer in a different league, it still retained a distinct imp stout profile. Splendid stuff, although I dont feel a pressing urge to drink it again any time soon; the price is discouraging and the intensity of the brew something I can only deal with so often. Cudos to BrewDog for their experiment, I really enjoyed Tactical Nuclear Penguin.

Sample at BrewDog Tasting at BeerTemple, bottle. I have to say this was a really small sample, so this will probably not be the most objective rating. Dark brown colour, thin head. Aroma was absolutely amazing, full of roasted malts, smoke, burnt sugar, peat, alcohol, coffee, vanilla, whiskey. Flavour is very sharp, sweet, roasted malts, alcohol, peat, iodine, ash. Medium to fullbodied. Dont really know what to think of this..

4cl sample@ Patricks. This was a fun experience. Too sweet to be a whisky and to strong to really be a beer, still many recognizable elements from both sides. Dark amber body with no head, almost a bit oily. The aroma is delicious, peated whisky, smoked malt, wood and quite strong alcoholic, pretty fantastic. Flavor is sweet, but not as sweet as Utopia, mild smoked malt, peated whisky with a bitter and alcoholic finish. Cant really decide how balanced this is, but its definitively drinkable in smaller quantities and a must try if youre not afraid of new flavors.

330 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 32%. Sold as "spirits / hard liquor" ( 4 cl shots) in Norway. Very dark reddish brown colour, nearly black. No head nor carbonation. Strong aroma of fusel alcohols, oaky and roasty notes, hints of smoke. Intense flavour of smoke, tar and salt. Moderately bitter finish. To be honest, this was not very good.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 City Beer Store, BrewDog night.  How exactly do you rate these super high alcohol beers?  I didnt enjoy it and wouldnt ever pay their asking price, but I also dont want to pan it as its an interesting exercise in brewing.  In terms of appearance, its dark brown with lighter highlights and no head.  Pretty good legs, I guess.  The smell is sorta acrid.  Bitter walnut shells and booze dominate the aroma.  Theres some big smoke and, maybe, caramel, but its all just kinda odd.  I was expecting it to taste more like whiskey, but its much too dirty and rough - makes me appreciate proper distillation.  Anyway, the flavor is even boozier and lacks the smoothness that I think necessary for this much alcohol.  Its not awful and theres a chance it could be quite good with a long, long stay in the cellar.  Im definitely not won over to the super high alcohol beers, though I definitely appreciate the effort.

Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Cool bag on the outside. Pours a nice dark tawny color with no head. Notes of soy, roasted malt, pure grain alcohol, and raisins. Hard to get many descriptors because this thing is so damn hot. Sticky long lasting mouthfeel.

Flavours are initially all about scotch whisky with plenty of peat and alcohol burn. Imperial stout come through near the end as the beer warms with roasted malt and burnt toffee bitterness. Mouth feel is quite thick and oily as expected. Not like anything I have tasted and certainly better than anticipated.

Pours rusty/brown with some amount of clarity, looks like a rum or liqueur in the glass. Very oily and leaves legs on the side of the glass. Aroma is pretty much all about Islay whisky characteristics. Salty, medicinal, smoky, iodine and of course boozy. Flavour is dominated by yet more Islay flavours, more iodine and peat/smoke, then into more chocolately territory, roasted-ish notes, raisins and dried fruits, itys quite hot and certainly warming on the throat and belly. Finish is spirit/liqueur-like with smoke still blowing about and residual sweetness. Its very hard to rate this beer with the Rate Beer point system, as palate rating and appearance are hard to pin down as both are not at all beer like and much more akin to a spirit. Im sure the, "Is it a beer or a liqueur?" debate will rage on for some time to come. AT the end of the day I respect the beer for its experimental nature and the fact that it has started some interesting debates around my part of the world. Is it over priced? Yes. Is it novelty? I think ot a degree. Is it clever marketing? Once again to a degree. Im glad Ive tried it, and most people should give it a go even if its split 6 ways as it still  marks a point in Beers evolution and its always best to see for yourself if something is marked "controversial."

Bottle @ RBWG 2010.  Ill give this beer the benefit of the doubt and say that I may not have the palate to fully understand and enjoy this beer.  Poured a dark, near black amber with no head.  The body I found a bit on the thin side and its almost  completely flat.  I can live with all that but all I got in both nose and flavor was the most over the top peat character with huge plastic, phenol notes.  I find this beer completely undrinkable.

When Im on my deathbed, I wont ask for extra time with my kid, or more sex with that girl in high school, or a better outside shot that would have given me a chance at pro basketball.   But I will want my $42 and the last hour of my life back.   Its not even that this is a silly waste of money (look, if you didnt know that when you bought it in the first place, youre not paying attention) its that it might be the worst "beer" Ive ever had.   I can drink just about any strong beer and find something redeeming.   Not this junk.   BrewDog should be embarrassed to be selling this as an "accomplishment."    It smells fine, nothing interesting, but nothing bad.   It seriously is one of the least drinkable concoctions Ive ever tried to put in my mouth, including the milk-and-mustard thing my friends tried to pay me to drink in junior high.   Oh, and the time I went down on that hippie chick after a night of dancing.  

I want to believe that its "complex" and "requires a more refined palate" (which I think I have) but no; the words my wife and I came up with were "impossible" and "the hurting" and "remember when that homeless guy came into the Whole Foods and starting peeing on the wall and they cleaned it up with some industrial cleaner and the mixture of the three smells was unlike anything youve smelled since Mardi Gras 95?  yeah, its like that."     Avoid this for all the right reasons -- spend the cash on any number of other fantastic extreme/micro/art beers that wont make your esophagus angry.

In long: Ok, how to go about rating a 32% beer?  First the thought of sharing a single 12oz bottle between many of us seemed kind of ridiculous.  But looking back at it I wish there could have been more of us.  So anyway, I get my 1.5oz sample and move aside with my notepad.  That thing costs a bundle so lets at least give it a fair review.
