19-MAR-2010, bottle with Ulkløbben - @home, from "Fish & Beer".
At last a taste of this much talked about beer.
We warmed up with Isle of Arran, Tokyo, and Tokyo* whole whatching the video, so we were properly trained beforehand:-)
But what is it?
Sticky sweet whiskey, fat lacings, no head. Difficult to really describe.
But the beer did exactly what I had hoped for: It started a long discussion. Is this really beer? Is it worth the price tag? Do I like it?
Well, fantastic beer, no matter the intention of it.

Sample from bottle at Stone Bistro.  Dark brown pour, little to no head.  Sweet syrupy malt, smoke, peat, strong caramel and dark fruit.  And naturally a lot of alcohol burn, this is a sipper for sure.  Actually decently enjoyable for how over the top it is.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, Feb 2010. I almost swallowed the first sips , because I thought it wasnt 32 %, but my throat told me the truth. No head and with a wonderful look. Notes of cask, port, oak, medicine, wood, caramel, brandy, raisin, coffee, licorice and tar. Its own special taste, maybe a mix of whisky and barley wine. Great experience....and remember to see the video!

Had this at Stone World Bistro and Gardens at their meet the brewer event last night. Sample from the bottle. Pours a deep brown, aromas of smoke, bacon, alcohol and peat. Very syrupy, raisin and smokey flavors but they  diminish quickly as the alcohol  takes over. Intense warming sensation. Drinks more like a liquor. Very nice, try some if you have the chance but be careful, it is 32%.

Bottle at Voldby BrewDog tasting. No head. Brown colour. Exploding powerfull Islay whisky aroma and flavor. Ashtray, medicin and all other nice stuff very present. Tastes more like whisky than beer. Really long fantastic finish. I am a sucker for Islay and alas fantastic "beer".
How speyside and deliver this much Islay notes I dont understand.....
Maybee the smokehead....
Sample at Voldby Brewdog tasting. No head. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are smoke, wood, caramel, roast malt, tar and alcohol. Funny experiment, but it is more funny than delightful.

Sample from bottle, at pre-ZBF March 5th, 2010. Pours very deep brown with a bit of an orange head; no head at all. Very syrupy, after swirling the glass is coated. Aroma of brandy with plenty of alcohol, and some raisin in the background. Raisin and cocoa hit the palate for an instant, and are then overcome by warming alcohol. Ash and peat join with the alcohol for a lengthy finish. The alcohol persists for quite a while (minutes) and as it subsides, earthy hops become evident. This was an interesting beer, and my favorite of the 2 ultra-ABV Brewdog beers I sampled at pre-ZBF.

bottle
this is some crazy ass beer. had to share with a few people. way to strong. I smelled alot of smoke,bacon, and tons of alcohol. Huge ass beer. more than i can handle. overall it was decent. glad i tried it, not something i would taste too often but glad i tried it.

RBWG10
Aroma, mostly peat, and not just peat, like spending a summer in a coalmine with some added malts and booze.
Flavor is just of a boozy mess of peat and some wood notes. 
I could see how it might appeal to nice whiskey drinkers, but this beer missed to impress as I faield to see how this one even fits a beer profile.

Light brown color with no head. Lightly sweet taste with a bit of roasty, caramel and dark fruit aroma. Wasnt sure what to expect, so it was a nice surprise how well the alcohol is hidden in this one.

Bottled:Deep red-ish brown, no head. Boozy aroma with notes of peat, liquorice and cough drops. Flavour is really intense and powerful, loads of salty tar, liquorice and peat. The taste of alcohol is well integrated with the other flavours and it turns out to be a great "sipping beer".

There should be a warning that says served slightly chilled or at room temperature on this.  Bottle, yeah i bought one.  Well served chilled the aroma is disguising nail polish remover, grain alcohol, and vodka esk.  Huge boozy with chemical sweetness.  However as this warms modestly it begins to open up.  Scotch like woodiness, chocolate and coco notes, roasted and peaty.  Hey i like scotch but this is a bit too much.  A fun novelty beer and an expensive lesson.

Bottle @ 3de Pre-ZBF. As far you can sa, its a clear black colored beer, with no head. The aroma of alcohol with dark fruits like raisins, in the back are tonsil. The taste of burned malts with fruits like prunes and tonsil, alcohol and very warm and burny. The aftertaste is mostly warm. Not bad and very drinkable, but for me its more like a liqueur.

4 cl from bottle at Black Door, Helsinki. Bright dark reddish brown color with no head. Sweetish thick toasty toffee aroma with dark caramel, port wine, perfumed berries and alcohol. Thick biscuity and bitter taste with port wine, marmelade and some burning alcohol. Dry charcoaly and smoky finish. Actually quite good substitute for a whisky. There are still some alcohol roughness from young age.

Bottle at pre-ZBF, served by Martin, courtesy of Keith - thank you sir!  Dark maroon color, no head, no lacing (they both drowned in alcohol).  Aroma is prunes, vanilla, dark fruits, brandy.  Taste is warm and tingly from tongue to belly, rich dark fruits, raisins, dates.  Nothing hidden about this one.  Best drunk in front of the fireplace while wearing your smoking jacket.

Tasted at PreZBF Festival, Belgium.
Poured near black with a minimal small lacing beige head. Aroma of a very characteristic porter one with a lot of liqueric fruits like plum, raisins, dark chocolate, cocoa. And because of high abv...some scotch or some burned/smoked sprit. Hard texture with roasted tastes like coffee and cocoa and of course, the liqueric, alcohol taste.  According to the incredible high abv, the alcohol is well hideden!

Bottle at Ryans Midtown Hotel room tasting post EBF 2010: Headless deep brown. Has a huge ethanol aroma initially. As it breathes some notes of cocoa, peat and quality Scotch comes through. Very hot, burns the palate. Lots of ethanol intially. As it warms and you swirl it a bit more peat and cocoa notes come through, displaying the qualities of an Islay Scotch. Too much burn, but I can see the appeal from a Scotch lovers perspective.
Bottle @ HJ Hansen, Odense. Pours pitch black with no head. Aroma & taste  is bitter and roasted with some sweet alcohol, soy and bacon. Heavy warmth. Sticky and oily. Flat carbonation.

Pours a clear brown, still, but with viscous legs on the glass.  Wow! Rubbing alcohol.  Smells like nothing but rubbing alcohol for the first few minutes. Bottle.

A: The pour is surprisingly "light" considering the fact that the base is an imperial stout. The beer is a light brown color with plenty of red highlights and not much in the way of head or carbonation.

S: Obviously, theres a large alcohol component to this beer at 32% ABV. That said, theres more to it than just the heat. Theres a slight caramel sweetness, vanilla, and a definite smokiness, almost peaty.

T: The alcohol heat takes a moment to get over, but after that, there are some decent flavors in there. The smoke and peat are a bit more pronounced than in the nose. Theres some vanilla, brown sugar, and caramel in the middle with a bitterness to the finish.

M: The lack of carbonation and huge amount of sweetness and alcohol make this too hot and a touch syrupy for my tastes.

D: This is one that Im glad to say that I tried. I honestly couldnt drink more than an ounce or two at once, and I think that perhaps in a couple decades, this might change a bit and become more palatable. As for now, I might taste it again, but I wouldnt seek it out.

I had a third of a bottle, and it was more than enough.

Big, Big and Big. Lots of whiskey, lots of peat, charcoal, dark chocolate, boozey. Not particularly full bodied. Surprisingly still beer like.  Decent, but a 1oz sample was sufficient.

Bottle in Tokyo at BEERS Brew Dog event. Dark brown-orange with no head at all. Whisky and cask aroma, big alcohol, oak. Wood and smoke big time in the flavor, with oak, licorice, a lick of charcoal. It is almost whiskey, but very much bears the flavor of beer. Very well done, interesting drink.

330mL bottle, generously provided by MarkDredge during Triple Rocks Sour Monday. Thanks, Mark! Pours a very deep, cola-brown color; a mostly headless pour; huge legs on this: very deep cola color. Huge, huge, huge nose here: lots of brown sugar, bacon, roasted and charred malts, and an intensely caramelized sugar character; hugely dense, to say nothing of the wood contribution: charred and toasty barrel character; again, loads of caramelized brown sugar, like brew kettle scrapings; certainly plenty of heat and warmth here, but its not fusels or anything poorly presented; loads of smoky, roasted meats. Full body: intensely oily and charred: smoke pipe, ash, burnt malts and intense warming presence here: lots of charred barrel and clear spirit notes, but never materializes into a complete fullness or roundness of flavor for me, it stays more to the perimeter of the mouth: the ashiness, the astringency, the alcohol and the charred notes; lots of heat, and I thought the aroma was far more clearly expressed; ashy, burnt, like scraping a reasonably tasty, burnt-out barrel. Im impressed by how this beer holds itself together, all told; I just cant imagine drinking a whole bottle of this by myself; certainly more of an insane ash cordial. Lasting, burnt finish: ash, charred oak, lots of leather notes at the far end.
Thanks Mark Dredge.  Poured dark reddish brown, alcohol, peat, roasted malts, wood, vanilla, little dark fruit, little caramel.

Pours dark brown with no head and a massive smoked peat aroma that actually drowns out the alcohol smell. The flavor is more pleasant than one would expect from this sort of brew, making this an interesting quaff.
Amazing wood expression and detail yes itiswarming.roasts are bright coffee roasts fantastic .better than expected

From botella, huge thanks yespr! Deep dark brown colour, no head at all. Whisky alco roasty malty smoky bit bacon aroma. Sticky pleasant mouthfeel. Bottle (shared, thanks Will!) 27th Jan 2010. Very, very dark brown and a bit oily. Nose is whisky alcohol. On the tongue, you get all the Paradox flavours amplified and intensified. Salty, dry finish.

ordered online from BrewDog - clear dark brown colour with absolutely no foam; very alcoholic nose with notes of bitter oranges, cognac and amaretti; very viscous and sticky, powerful malt body, chocolatey and nutty with solid alcohol notes; strong bitterness and roasted - very good

very viscous.  big whiskey aroma blast.  lingering burn all the way down.  peat taste to it.  bit of sparkle on the tongue.  surprisingly easy to drink.  you can debate if this is beer or spirits all night.  i fall down on the "not beer" side.

Ok, so I dont really go for Islay notes, let alone whisky.  But this was intriguing.  Whether I would have got this myself or it was on the radar at work, I dont know.    Packaging and marketing was excellent.  Took this to good friends 40th Birthday with plenty of very "dedicated beer people" -  so much to say that it was served in little goblets, for about 12 people.    That was about enough for me.   I honestly believe that congratulations are deserved for this, the attempt and delivery of this truely out there style.   Hell, I rarely rate, and this is the longest rate that I have written in years.   This "beer" is more akin to a spirit, so I think I will be treating it that way, small serves, shared at desert with coffee, perhaps.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2010 Bottle generously shared by Nick3 on BA - thanks, Nick.  *COUGH* gimmick! *COUGH*  Im glad I got to try what was briefly (before the release of Schorschbräu Schorschbock 40%) the worlds *COUGH* biggest gimmick! *COUGH* strongest beer.  Wow, I really seem to have a terrible cough today.  In all seriousness though, this "beer" is definitely interesting, although overpriced and overhyped.  I liked it more than others at the tasting, but make no mistake, it will floor you.  I feel weird calling this a beer, as it was a lot more like a liquor.

Pours very dark brown with a small tan head and great legs.  This is a thick one for sure.

Aroma is very hot and boozy, like a rough scotch.  Sweet caramel, roast, oak, and vanilla poke through the intense alcohol.

The most prominent flavor in this beer is BOOOOOOOOOOOZE!  I didnt add all those Os for the hell of it.  Youre going to taste every bit of that 32% ABV.  Bud Select 55 this is not.  Definitely too hot.  Someone else at the tasting commented that they should have eised and then -bal aged this, not the other way around.  I agree.  10 years or so of age might do this beer good.  Once you get past the booze though, its a nice beer.  Roasted malt and caramel malt, toffee, oak, and mild peat smoke.  Like a Scotch, this needs time to round out.  Poor execution there on BrewDogs part in my opinion.

Hot and boozy on the palate with good carbonation, unlike most other beers this strong, and fairly full body.  Crazy beer overall, just crazy.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 33cl bottle from the brewery. Batch 001. Best before 2019-11. It was with great anticipation I poured this beer from the bottle and into a Delirium Tremens glass. I thought the glass was appropriate as this beer is almost guaranteed to give you Delirium Tremens (the condition that is, not the beer). The colour is pitch black with no visible head. Suprisingly there was some carbonation in the beginning. Dont know why, but the texture seemed a bit thin. The aroma is, not suprisingly, massive and laden with alcohol. Some smoke, oak and roasted malts as well. The first impressions of the flavour is smooth and balanced, but it doesnt take very long for the flavour to go nuclear. Massive alcohol of course, but also liqorice, smoke, rye, roasted malts and tar. The flavour lingers in the mouth a long time. This beer has received a lot of attention and not without merit, although Id classify this more as a fun experiment than a very good beer, but the whisky-crowd would probably appreciate it more. Since this was the first batch it could be interesting to see if the second batch is different.

Pours out a deep black with a hint of ruby brown.  The nose is absolutely amazing, hugely complex, all sorts going on, twiglets, liquorice, smoke, peat, marmite, black malts, coffee, milk chocolate. Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks to Yespr. Clear dark brown - no head. High whiskey, roasted, smokey, ashtray, wooden, burned, sharpness, light acetone, licorice, high malty. Interesting - very nice - but not much of a beer.... more like a whiskey.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2010 A Mes rate. Bottle at Chris Os Night of the Gaylords.Very dark amber and still somehow managing to hold onto a slim head. Good effort! Aroma is just oh my GOD wow. Amazing complexity. Full of coffee and black fruity maltiness, not over the top with the alcohol amazingly and the Smokehead  is peeking through too. General madness and incredibly sniffable. The flavour just can not hold a candle to the aroma unfortunately. All heat and burn and just far too much. Not unpleasant by any means and all that I love about the aroma is evident but its all killed by raw alcohol. Almost brilliant but just too much burn for me.Re-rate. Bottle at the Jolly Gardeners thanks to the ever generous BrewDog folks.My god. This has really developed. Its settled down beautifully. Yes, the heat is still there obviously but its much more tollerable now. Drinks like half the strength and now it does, the adorable smoky goodness of the aroma is much more apparent. I stand by my aroma notes, its still just as good but the flavour has gone through the roof compared with how it was closer to the release. This is now whisky concentrate with some amazing dark maltiness. Stunning salt, seaweed, peat and Isla brilliance. Just a tiny sip is like holding a massive gob full of whisky in your mouth. My palate gives way fully and invites it in with open arms. Its like in Spinal Tap where they point out the amps turn up to eleven. This is beer turned up to eleven. Small sips, small servings huuuuge payback. Fantastic. Im not drunk yet I promise. Im just really impressed with how well this has matured. Great stuff folks.

Bottle, huge thanks to yespr for sharing.
Clear red brown coloured with a small off white head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of alcohol, liquorice and whisky.
Roasted flavour of alcohol, liquorice, whisky, cough drops and hops with notes of salt water.
Hoppy and warming alcoholic finish.

Props to whoever brought this along to Chris. Given the hype I was expecting to not like it, but was glad to be wrong, because this was great. Whiskey-ish malt notes, but very smooth and the 32% is very well hidden in my opinion, but in saying that it does taste strong. Kind of a little bit woody or oaky or something, I have no idea if they give this any oak treatment. Some light notes of vanilla, tar, vegemite or marmite or something, dark fruits, some saltyness coming through, with a dry, whiskey-sh, spirity finish. Very nice, well done.

This is one hell of a beer wrapping. Its a real shame that you cant see it on the pic. Wrapped in a brown "New-York-Style" paper bag with a penguin drawed by hand on - soooo cool. And then - to be the strongest beer in the world is quite some. Ditch the mainstreem and say hello to Brew Dog. The pour is dark brown with massive curtains when rolled in the glass. There are no head at all, so the appearenced isnt that convincing. The nose is massive whiskey like - and that is the smoked islay kind of whisky - smoked as hell. Underneeth the smoke and hard core alcohol there is some licorice andvulcanic  sulphur. The taste is sweet with a very very strong (and unbalanced) taste of alcohol. There is some salmiac and some sweet notes somewhere. Its burning in your mouth and when lit it burns on a tee spoon - this one is serious buisness and to me it most of all taste like a whiskey and beer mixed halfn half. The palate is much thinner than I would have expected and I will almost call it watery taking in mind that we are dealing with an imperial stout - and lets stress it again -  a very strong one. Glad to have tasted this one..but its over the top.

Quite much black colour with not too much head. Aroma is whiskylike stinging alcohol, quite much liquorice as well as some rather burnt sugary notes. Flavour is quite much the same. Rather whiskyish stinging alcohol in this one, not that balanced...

Bottled. A deep red beer with a thin tan head. The aroma has strong notes of alcohol, smoke, wood, roasted malt, and some caramel, and dextrose. The flavor is very sweet with strong notes of dextrose, caramel, and alcohol, as well as medium notes of caramel, malt, smoke, and wood, leading to a dry finish - drying out from the smoke, the whiskey, the wood, and the alcohol. The body is extremely powerful. In all aspects extreme. Huge thanks to yespr for sharing this beer.
Clear mahogany with nearly no head. Powerfull, wiskey, smoke and roasted malt. Flavour had whiskey, roasted malt, smoke, oak, vanilla and ripe fruits. Smoked finish with warming alcohol.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a clear orangey brown with no head. Intensely burning and alcoholic nose with some tar and smoke also. Solid body, completely flat, burning whisky accents, smokey, ashy, peaty and woody. The alcohol really burns your lips and down your throat. Alcoholic AND hoppy finish. A most perfect sipper - and certainly one of the best extreme beers Ive had. 100110

Thanks to Phil for the glass. Pours almost black with no head. Huge burning fusel nose with lots of roast as well. Insanely complex with chocolate, coffee, roast beef, and of course, a solid dose of alcohol. A burn not as bad as expected finishes the flavor with moderate bitterness. Medium mouthfeel.

Salty mouthfeel, burning, with bitter caramel and some liquorice; strong chocolate too. Strong alcohol feeling. The aroma is alcoholic, suddenly whisky-like, then some caramel too, finally some chocolate and sweaty hop. Strong mouthfeel, caramel flavor, overwhelmed by the alcohol.At first, it reminds me an Italian amaro (herbs digestive liquor), but the alcohol is too present, and there is no herbal character. UPDATED: JAN 17, 2010 Intense. It looks great, love the bottle and the brown bag. In the glass its a black-amber with long legs hanging to the sides. Gorgeous aroma. The taste is hot, its big, its rich, its boozy. Its a beer to try, one to share with a few of people and be treated like a whisky. I shared this with two mates after a long tasting and a bottle of 1985 port. It was a good finish to the night. The more I drink this the more I enjoy it.

Small beige head. Dark red body tinged with brown. Intense chocolate salt toffee and malts aroma with peaty whisky caramel notes. Dense syrupy mouthfeel with intense alcohol burn. Strong sugary alcoholic earthy chocolatey salt taste with peaty smoky treacle notes. Very full body. Bitter alcohol, smoke, and whisky aftertaste. "Notes" is kind of misleading for this beer, which doesnt deal in subtleties. Absolutely outrageously intense. Really more like a whisky. (Small taster at Brewdog tasting at Dr Jekylls.)

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2010 33 cL bottle, bursted within 3 hours upon its arrival at my home, funny break just beneath the neck of the bottle and once I had emptied the bottle I saw that the bottom had burst into pieces. I could rescue alot - but the table still looked like a mess. At first I though a fuse had blown - but as the intense dark malt, alcohol and tarish smoke notes started to fill the room I knew what had happened. Shit happens. Aroma is intense - my table still smells like the inside of a whiskey barrel :) No head on what I rescued - however the content inside the bottle showed a small head. Flavour is burningly intense. Much like a whiskey just thicker and more dark i flavour. Solid tarish and with an intense alcoholburn. Ever lasting smoked, tarish and intense roasted malt flavour. More whiskey than beer - but certainly a nice sipper.
Bottle at Craigs house. Wow. Very neat. Would like to say I liked it but it was certainly unique!! Must try!

Taste from a bottle from MagicDave, thanks Tom.  Black no head.  Harsh aroma of whisky ice cream.  Hot Worcestershire sauce aroma, even meaty.  Its like a spirit.  Not like a beer.  Aroma is wonderful.  Choc and caramel and some hot alcohol.  It takes over your whole body.  Way too hot.  Good but way too bizarre.  Coffe and malt loaf on aroma too.  Great aroma of lots of different aromas and flavours.

RATING 2500! A couple of bottles shared with several other lucky folks courtesy of Vlado & Liliana from Roland + Russell, the importers of Brewdog for Canada - many thanks to them for this pre-Christmas treat! First, I must confess that this isnt actually the 2500th beer Ive had since starting on RateBeer - Ive currently got a backlog of several hundred ratings in notebooks, and have been entering ratings very haphazardly and out of order for the past year or so. But when I found out that I was going to have a chance to try this, I decided to use it for this big milestone anyway. So, as for the beer - it has a deep brown-black colour with ruby highlights and a very still body. Aroma is outstanding - smoky, peaty, salty, soy sauce, toffee, and some alcohol heat, but not nearly as much as expected. Mouthfeel is smooth and supple, very nice! Flavour is deep and complex with notes of peat, salt, vanilla, licorice, burnt wood, whisky, smoke... and yes, of course, some boozy heat, but as with the aroma, not nearly as much as I anticipated from 32%. A truly unique and absolutely delicious beer that totally lives up to the hype. I would have no problem consuming a whole bottle of this over the course of a long winters evening, although it would be rude not to share...

Appearance:  Pours like dark roast coffee with no head.

Aroma:  Liquid smoke, bbq potato chips, rubber cement. The alcohol is so strong it burns the back of my nose.

Taste: Wood, what Id imagine paint to taste based on how it smells, soy sauce, M & Ms, barbecue sauce, toasted nuts,dark roasted coffee and burnt malts.

Mouthfeel: Warm and thick.

Overall: This beer was pretty over the top and obnoxious. This beer should steal the show at any tasting, and will actually warm you up quite a bit. I did not consume the entire bottle myself, and I dont think I could anyhow.

WOW. Very full bottle, glad it didnt explode, shared between three people. Dont think a bottle each would have enabled a coherent review to be written! Bottle pours a viscous black oily beer, with absolutely no head. Aroma is predominantly smoke, with strong alcohol notes and underlying sweetness. Leaves greasy residue on side of glass. Thick tingling mouthfeel coats inside of mouth, imparting heavy flavours of wood, caramel, smoky, peaty whisky. A knockout, and a cracking nightcap.

Ill qualify my rating by saying this was a one ounce sample poured to me by James from BrewDog while they were at the Flying Saucer in Houston, TX early in December.  The pour was black and viscous with a few brown bubbles sticking together on the peripheries.  The aroma was peat, smoked meats, alcohol, caramel and vanilla.  The flavor was a blend of salty and sweet.  Smoked meats up front gave way to a bit of caramel sweetness that was quickly snowed under by a surge of warming alcohol.  The mouthfeel was full bodied, thick and coating but never cloying.  The closest thing I could compare this too in terms of how if felt would be Triple Bock.

A hedonistic whiskey brew recommended for fans of Dark Island Reserve and Ola Dubh series. One killer beer. Shared many thanks with Magic Dave. I really appreciate the special tastings. The alcohol was heavy in epic poportions. Notes of caramel; roasted malts and coffee. However not too sure as I was too blown away by seeing it and the abv.

I tried to remember on the way home what my rating was. Ah thats a good beer and well worth seeking out to store away. Thank you Brew Dog for sticking it to the media yet again.

From bottle at BrewDog tasting, Oslo, Dec 09.
Smoke, tar and chocolate in the nose.
Treacle, tar, old ropes. Strong alcohol, yet very hoppy. Liquorice, salt, brandy.
Smoke and fire in the finish.

Alcohol seems hiden then in the finish comes and punches you in the tear well, but your half in half between crying with joy and pain. Win on a level that i want to punch myself?
